Job.JobDescription:
The Coach (Title Unconfirmed) at Dublin is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Coach (Title Unconfirmed) is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Dublin, the Coach (Title Unconfirmed) helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Coach (Title Unconfirmed) may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Dublin well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Coach (Title Unconfirmed) follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

The Head JV Girls Golf Coach at Dublin is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Head JV Girls Golf Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Dublin, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Head JV Girls Golf Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Head JV Girls Golf Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Dublin operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Dublin with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Head JV Girls Golf Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Head JV Girls Golf Coach role at Dublin.

The Assistant Varsity Swimming Coach position at Dublin is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Assistant Varsity Swimming Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Dublin, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Assistant Varsity Swimming Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Assistant Varsity Swimming Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Assistant Varsity Swimming Coach role at Dublin is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The Boys Golf Coach role at Dublin is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Boys Golf Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Dublin are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Boys Golf Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Boys Golf Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Boys Golf Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Dublin, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Boys Golf Coach at Dublin, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The Wrestling Coach - Junior High position at McCord is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Wrestling Coach - Junior High works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Wrestling Coach - Junior High at McCord sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At McCord, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Wrestling Coach - Junior High encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Wrestling Coach - Junior High is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Wrestling Coach - Junior High position at McCord is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.
Job.CompanyDescription: Sylvania City School District coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription: Effective Date(s): March 9, 2026 - June 15, 2026 Staff Needed: One (1) Head Coach Softball Qualifications: • New Jersey Teacher's Certificate OR Substitute Teacher Certificate; proof of experience required for substitute certificate holder • Coaching experience preferred, but not required • Must be available daily during the fall sports season • Must be certified in CPR and AED, and holding a current certificate in both • Must obtain a "Concussion Awareness and Wellness" certificate or its equivalent, renewed annually • Must Obtain a "Heat Acclimatization Awareness and Wellness" certificate or it's equivalent, renewed annually. • All new coaches will have one year after being hired to successfully complete a course in "Sports First Aid".
Job.Experience: Coaching experience preferred, but not required

Job.JobDescription: Effective Date(s): March 09, 2026 - June 06, 2026 Staff Needed: Three (3) Assistant Coaches - Softball Qualifications: DOE Certification Requirements (including volunteer coaches) must have one of the two certifications: o New Jersey Teacher's Certification o New Jersey Instructional Substitute Credential (30 College Credits) Proof of experience required for Substitute Certificate holder. Coaching experience preferred but not required. Must be available daily during the winter sports season. All coaches must hold a current (valid) adult CPR/AED and Basic First Aid Certification. All courses that the DOE approves for certification are acceptable. All new coaches (starting 2007-2008 school year) must complete the NFHS Fundamentals of Coaching Course before their first employment as a coach. This course is a one-time requirement. All coaches must complete the NFHS Concussion in Sports Course, renewed annually. All coaches must complete the NFHS Heat Illness Prevention Course, renewed annually. All coaches must complete the NFHS Implicit Bias Course. This course is a one-time requirement. All coaches must complete the BeNice Program. This course is a one-time requirement. Salary: $6,087.00 - $7,229.00 Initiator: Tororris J. Hill, Athletic Supervisor Meet such alternatives to the above qualifications as the Superintendent may find appropriate and acceptable. Pending budget availability. All postings are open for ten (10) consecutive days following the date posted or until filled.

Kennedy High School-Athletics Date Available: 03/09/2026 Closing Date: 03/09/2026 Effective Date(s): March 9, 2026 - June 15, 2026 Staff Needed: One (1) Head Coach Baseball Qualifications: - New Jersey Teacher's Certificate OR Substitute Teacher Certificate; proof of experience required for substitute certificate holder - Coaching experience preferred, but not required - Must be available daily during the fall sports season - Must be certified in CPR and AED, and holding a current certificate in both - Must obtain a "Concussion Awareness and Wellness" certificate or its equivalent, renewed annually - Must Obtain a "Heat Acclimatization Awareness and Wellness" certificate or it's equivalent, renewed annually. - All new coaches will have one year after being hired to successfully complete a course in "Sports First Aid". Salary: $9,006.00 - $10,529.00
Job.Experience: Coaching experience preferred, but not required

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Coach - Softball role at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Assistant Coach - Softball is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At John F. Kennedy Memorial High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Assistant Coach - Softball sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At John F. Kennedy Memorial High School, the Assistant Coach - Softball is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Assistant Coach - Softball at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball role at Colonia High School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Colonia High School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Colonia High School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Colonia High School.

Job.JobTitle: Football Fall Coaching Positions (Head Coach, Head Assistant Coach, Assistant Coaches)
Job.JobDescription:
The Football Fall Coaching Positions (Head Coach, Head Assistant Coach, Assistant Coaches) at Perth Amboy High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Football Fall Coaching Positions (Head Coach, Head Assistant Coach, Assistant Coaches) plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Perth Amboy High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Football Fall Coaching Positions (Head Coach, Head Assistant Coach, Assistant Coaches) expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Football Fall Coaching Positions (Head Coach, Head Assistant Coach, Assistant Coaches) supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Football Fall Coaching Positions (Head Coach, Head Assistant Coach, Assistant Coaches) may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Perth Amboy High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Assistant Cross Country
Job.JobDescription:
Title: Athletic Coach - Assistant Cross Country Work Location: Gallup High School Contract Length: Fall Sport Minimum Salary: $6,000.00 Maximum Salary: $6,000.00
*Internal applicants MUST attach a signed Permission to Coach Form to application*
ATHLETIC COACHING LICENSE, 7-12
High School Diploma or Equivalency AND Must hold or have the ability to obtain an Athletic Coaching License (https://webnew.ped.state.nm.us/bureaus/licensure/how-to-apply/athletic-coach-7-12/) from the New Mexico Public Education Department as well as completing the Fundamentals of Coaching online exam offered through the New Mexico Activities Association. (www.nmact.org)
QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program. 2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports) 3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Mid School Baseball (4 positions)
Job.JobDescription:
*Internal applicants MUST attach a signed Permission to Coach Form to application*
ATHLETIC COACHING LICENSE, 7-12
High School Diploma or Equivalency AND Must hold or have the ability to obtain an Athletic Coaching License (https://webnew.ped.state.nm.us/bureaus/licensure/how-to-apply/athletic-coach-7-12/) from the New Mexico Public Education Department as well as completing the Fundamentals of Coaching online exam offered through the New Mexico Activities Association. (www.nmact.org)
QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program. 2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports) 3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions.
REPORTS TO: The athletic director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principals.
WORK ENVIRONMENT: On-site attendance is mandatory for this position.
SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal.
JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self-discipline, self-confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc.
Work with students interested in sports, provide necessary practice support and advice for a team to be successful against opposing teams in a sports season. Teach and enforce rules and regulations. Involves work on evenings and weekends.

The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - E-Sports role at Thoreau High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. The Volunteer Assistant Wrestling Coach position at Tibbetts Middle School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Volunteer Assistant Wrestling Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Volunteer Assistant Wrestling Coach at Tibbetts Middle School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Tibbetts Middle School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Volunteer Assistant Wrestling Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Volunteer Assistant Wrestling Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Volunteer Assistant Wrestling Coach position at Tibbetts Middle School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The Assistant Varsity Coach will supervise practice, contests, travel, equipment and other requirements related to the sport they are coaching. They are to ensure student safety and eligibility for participating in the sport. Essential Duties and Responsibilities: Responsibility and Authority Supervisors are the head coach, athletic director, and principal. Shared authority with the head coach over all players and season related activities. Job Responsibilities o Supervise students during practices and games including locker room, around the building, and gym area o Ensure participants maintain acceptable standards of behavior and decorum. o Assist in conducting and supervising practices throughout the sport season. Complete other tasks as assigned by the head coach. Qualifications: Appropriate National and/or State Coaching Certifications. Physical Requirements: Sitting, standing, lifting and carrying (up to 50 pounds), reaching, squatting, kneeling, prolonged typing, physical ability to type on a keyboard terminal, and moving equipment may be required. Equipment/Technology Handled: Must know how to properly operate or be willing to learn to operate equipment related to the sport, computer and other equipment as needed. Work Environment: Must be able to work within various degrees of noise, temperature, and air quality. Interruptions of work are routine. Flexibility and patience are required. Must be self-motivated and able to complete job assignment without direct supervision. After hour work may be required. Terms of Employment: Salary and work calendar established yearly by the district.

General Job Description: The Head Varsity Coach will supervise practice, contests, travel, equipment and other requirements related to the sport they are coaching. They are to ensure student safety and eligibility for participating in the sport.
Essential Duties and Responsibilities:
Maintain an accurate and updated list of supplies and equipment. Submit a copy of the season wrap-up form to the Athletic Director within two (2) weeks of the last contest; include major equipment/uniform needs Check in equipment at the end of the season. Charge students for lost equipment. Store and secure uniforms, equipment, and supplies within two (2) weeks of the last contest. Ensure that each participant has a physical examination form turned in to the office prior to participating in practice. Collect the insurance forms and training rules before the first practice. Submit copy of policies to the Athletic Director Organize, conduct, and supervise practices throughout the season. Notify Athletic Office of practice schedules and changes in practice schedules. Clear athletes from the gymnasium, locker room, and weight room before leaving the building. See that participants do not loiter around the building or in the halls immediately after practice Supervise students during practices and games inclusive of locker room, gymnasium and gym lobby Ride the bus to and from all contests Require that participants maintain acceptable standards of behavior and decorum Provide team and player publicity to local media Attend end-of-season awards banquet and present season awards Establish written expectations for assistants. Provide a copy of these expectations to the coaching staff and administrators Develop comprehensive programs for the off season Check eligibility each grading period. Discrepancies are resolved through the Athletic Director Provide all necessary information on time to appropriate offices (i.e., excused absence list prior to departure) Accept other responsibilities and duties as deemed necessary by supervisor
Qualifications: Appropriate National and/or State Coaching Certifications.
Physical Requirements: Sitting, standing, lifting and carrying (up to 50 pounds), reaching, squatting, kneeling, prolonged typing, physical ability to type on a keyboard terminal, and moving equipment may be required.
Equipment/Technology Handled: Must know how to properly operate or be willing to learn to operate equipment related to the sport, computer and other equipment as needed.
Work Environment: Must be able to work within various degrees of noise, temperature, and air quality. Interruptions of work are routine. Flexibility and patience are required. Must be self-motivated and able to complete job assignment without direct supervision. After hour work may be required.
Terms of Employment: Salary and work calendar established yearly by the district.

The Assistant coach Football volunteer role at Hermosa Middle School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Assistant coach Football volunteer coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Hermosa Middle School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Assistant coach Football volunteer reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Hermosa Middle School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Assistant coach Football volunteer may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Assistant coach Football volunteer monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Assistant coach Football volunteer must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Hermosa Middle School.

This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. At the core of the job is teaching. The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At HEIZER MIDDLE SCHOOL, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Assistant 8th Grade Boys Track Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Assistant 8th Grade Boys Track Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The Assistant Middle School Football Coach at HEIZER MIDDLE SCHOOL is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Assistant Middle School Football Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At HEIZER MIDDLE SCHOOL, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Assistant Middle School Football Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Assistant Middle School Football Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Assistant Middle School Football Coach at HEIZER MIDDLE SCHOOL allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Roswell Independent School District Job Description Job Title: HEAD COACH Reports To: ATHLETIC COORDINATOR – HIGH SCHOOL/DIRECTOR OF ATHLETICS/ACTIVITIES General Job Description: Responsible for all aspects of the Athletic program for their respective sport. Essential Duties and Responsibilities: 1. Follows state, regional, and district policies. 2. Responsible to the high school athletic coordinator and is responsible for its implementation by the entire staff of the sports program. 3. Provides strong leadership for assistants and athletes in the program. 4. Advises the activities director and recommends policy, method or procedural changes. 5. Provides proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment sites. 6. Assists the athletic director in scheduling, providing transportation, and requirements for tournaments and special sport events. 7. Provides documentation to fulfill state and system requirements concerning physical examinations, parental consent and eligibility. 8. Maintain discipline, adjusts grievances, and works to increase morale and cooperation. 9. Delegates specific duties, supervises implementation, and at season’s end, analyze staff effectiveness and evaluates all assistants. 10. Established the fundamental philosophy, skills and techniques to be taught by staff. 11. Designs conferences, clinics and staff meetings to insure staff awareness of over-all program. 12. Trains and informs staff and encourages professional growth by encouraging clinic attendance according to local clinic policy. 13. Presents information to news media concerning schedules, tournaments and results. 14. Responsible for the quality, effectiveness and validity of any oral or written release to local media. 15. Responsible for maintaining good public relations with news media, booster clubs, parents, officials, volunteers and fans. 16. Promotes the sport within the school through recruiting athletes that are not in another sports program and promotes the sport outside the school through news media, Little League programs or any other feasible manner. 17. Determine student discipline, delineates procedures concerning due process when the enforcement of discipline is necessary. 18. Gives constant attention to a student athlete’s grades and conduct. 19. Assists athletes in their college or advanced educational selection. 20. Directs student managers, assistants and statisticians. 21. Completes paperwork on all disabling athletic injuries on proper forms and submits to the athletic office within 24 hours. 22. Provides training rules and any other unique regulations of the sport to each athletic who is considered a participant. 23. By his/her presence at all practices, games and while traveling provides assistance, guidance and safeguards for each participant. 24. Initiates programs and policies concerning injuries, medical attention and emergencies. 25. Is accountable for all equipment and collects the cost of any equipment lost or not returned. Arranges for issuing, storing, and reconditioning of equipment and submits annual inventory and current records concerning this equipment. 26. Monitors equipment rooms and coaches offices, and authorizes who may enter issue or requisition equipment. 27. Permits the athletes to only be in authorized areas of the building at the appropriate times. 28. Instills in each player a respect for equipment and school property, its care and its proper usage. 29. Maintain confidentiality with sensitive matters. 30. Be flexible and able to prioritize tasks and maintain accurate and detailed records. Knowledge of universal hygiene precautions (blood borne pathogens, body fluids, etc.) Equipment/Material Handled: Must know how to properly operate, or be willing to learn to operate, multi-media equipment including current technology as needed. Work Environment: Must be able to work within various degrees of noise and temperature. Interruptions of work are routine. Flexibility and patience are required. Must be self-motivated and able to complete job assignments without direct supervision. After hours work may be required. May be required to make home and site visits. May work under stressful conditions on occasion. Terms of Employment: Salary and work year to be established by the Board. Position Type: Increment Salary: $3,000 Per Year
Job.Location: Goddard High School - Athletics - Roswell, New Mexico

Job.JobDescription: Roswell Independent School District Job Description Job Title: ASSISTANT COACH Reports To: HEAD COACH/PRINCIPAL/DIRECTOR OF ATHLETICS/ACTIVITIES Essential Duties and Responsibilities: 1. Has knowledge of existing system and State and NMAA regulations. 2. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Roswell Independent School District Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation. 3. Has knowledge of the existing system, state and league regulations and implements them consistently. 4. Understands the proper administrative line of command and refers all requests or grievances through proper channels. 5. Is aware of all public/staff/departmental meetings that require attendance. 6. Maintains liaisons with adjoining schools, colleges, and agencies. 7. Has a thorough knowledge of the athletic policy and is responsible for its implementation. 8. Knows the procedures to follow to initiate the process for athletic eligibility and is responsible for its implementation. 9. Establishes the fundamental philosophy, skills and techniques to be taught by the staff. 10. Designs conferences, clinics and staff meetings to insure staff awareness of overall program. 11. Trains and informs staff and encourages professional growth by encouraging clinic attendance according to local policy. 12. Delegates specific duties, supervises implementation, and at season’s end, analyzes staff effectiveness and evaluates all assistants. 13. Maintains discipline and works to increase morale and cooperation. 14. Assists in the necessary preparation to hold scheduled sport events or practices and adheres to scheduled facility times. 15. Provides documentation to fulfill state and system requirements concerning physical examinations, parent consent and eligibility. 16. Provides proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment and sites. 17. Advises the head coach and recommends policy, method or procedural changes. 18. Completes paperwork on all disabling athletic injuries on proper forms and submits to athletic office within 24 hours. 19. Attends all staff meetings and carries out scouting assignments as outlined by the head coach. 20. Arrives prior to the beginning of practice, contests and meetings. 21. Arrives early enough before practice, contests and meetings to adequately prepare and remains long enough afterwards to help players with problems or to become involved in staff discussions. 22. Never criticizes, admonishes or argues with head coach or any staff member within ears or eyes of players or parents. 23. Helps in the planning and implementation of both in-season and out-or-season conditioning and weight programs as is possible. 24. Attends most of the contests, when possible, or other teams in the program. 25. Strives to improve skills by attending clinics and using resources made available by the head coach. 26. Performs such other duties that are consistent with the nature of the position and that may be requested by the head coach. 27. Maintain confidentiality with sensitive matters. 28. Be flexible and able to prioritize tasks and maintain accurate and detailed records. 29. Report to work on time and evening /weekend hours are applicable. 30. Attempt to deescalate students/parents/staff, listening/visiting with them about their concerns prior to them meeting with administrators. 31. May be required to perform other duties/functions as directed by supervisor. ASSISTANT COACH (CONT’D) Supervisory Responsibilities: Students in his charge. Qualifications: 1. High School diploma or GED. 2. Current NM Coaching licensure including CPR/AED Certification. 3. Valid Driver’s license and Car Insurance. 4. Ability to drive from site to site as needed. Physical Requirements: Sitting, standing, lifting and carrying (up to 40 pounds), climbing stairs, reaching, squatting, kneeling, having full mobility of fingers/hands, and moving light furniture may be required, unless ADA accommodations have been mutually agreed on and does not create an undue hardship upon the district. Work Environment: Must be able to work within various degrees of noise and temperature. Interruptions of work are routine. Flexibility and patience are required. Must be self-motivated and able to complete job assignments without direct supervision. After hours work may be required. May be required to make home and site visits. May work under stressful conditions on occasion. Terms of Employment: Salary and work year to be established by the Board. Position Type: Increment Salary: $3,200 Per Year Job Categories: Athletics & Activities > Coaching
Job.Location: Goddard High School - Athletics - Roswell, New Mexico

Job.JobDescription:
The VHS-Assistant Powerlifting Coach 25-26 role at Los Lunas Public Schools is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the VHS-Assistant Powerlifting Coach 25-26 is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Los Lunas Public Schools, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The VHS-Assistant Powerlifting Coach 25-26 sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Los Lunas Public Schools, the VHS-Assistant Powerlifting Coach 25-26 is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the VHS-Assistant Powerlifting Coach 25-26 at Los Lunas Public Schools is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.
Job.Location: VHS Athletics - Los Lunas, New Mexico
Job.SalaryRange: As established by the Los Lunas Schools current Increment Salary Schedule. As per NMAA Season.
Job.CompanyDescription: Los Lunas Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The VMS- SOFTBALL COACH-25-26 role at Los Lunas Public Schools is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the VMS- SOFTBALL COACH-25-26 is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Los Lunas Public Schools are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The VMS- SOFTBALL COACH-25-26 listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the VMS- SOFTBALL COACH-25-26 encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The VMS- SOFTBALL COACH-25-26 follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Los Lunas Public Schools, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the VMS- SOFTBALL COACH-25-26 at Los Lunas Public Schools, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.
Job.Location: VMS Athletics - Los Lunas, New Mexico
Job.SalaryRange: As established by the Los Lunas Schools current Increment Salary Schedule. As per NMAA Season.
Job.CompanyDescription: Los Lunas Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The VHS-ASSISTANT SOFTBALL COACH 25-26 role at Los Lunas Public Schools emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the VHS-ASSISTANT SOFTBALL COACH 25-26 coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Los Lunas Public Schools, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The VHS-ASSISTANT SOFTBALL COACH 25-26 reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Los Lunas Public Schools at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The VHS-ASSISTANT SOFTBALL COACH 25-26 may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The VHS-ASSISTANT SOFTBALL COACH 25-26 monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The VHS-ASSISTANT SOFTBALL COACH 25-26 must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Los Lunas Public Schools.
Job.Location: VHS Athletics - Los Lunas, New Mexico
Job.CompanyDescription: Los Lunas Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The VMS- Baseball Coach 25-26 at Los Lunas Public Schools is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the VMS- Baseball Coach 25-26 plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Los Lunas Public Schools reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The VMS- Baseball Coach 25-26 expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the VMS- Baseball Coach 25-26 supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the VMS- Baseball Coach 25-26 may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Los Lunas Public Schools. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.
Job.Location: VMS Athletics - Los Lunas, New Mexico
Job.SalaryRange: As established by the Los Lunas Schools current Increment Salary Schedule. As per NMAA Season.
Job.CompanyDescription: Los Lunas Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Coach - Track - 7/8, Chaparral Middle School(ATH-433)
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Coach - Track - 7/8, Chaparral Middle School position at Alamogordo Public Schools is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Assistant Coach - Track - 7/8, Chaparral Middle School is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Alamogordo Public Schools, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Assistant Coach - Track - 7/8, Chaparral Middle School encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Assistant Coach - Track - 7/8, Chaparral Middle School also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Assistant Coach - Track - 7/8, Chaparral Middle School role at Alamogordo Public Schools is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: Coach Assistant Boys Basketball High School Posting 550
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach Assistant Boys Basketball High School Posting 550 role at Los Alamos High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Coach Assistant Boys Basketball High School Posting 550 is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Los Alamos High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Coach Assistant Boys Basketball High School Posting 550 listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Coach Assistant Boys Basketball High School Posting 550 encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Coach Assistant Boys Basketball High School Posting 550 follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Los Alamos High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Coach Assistant Boys Basketball High School Posting 550 at Los Alamos High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Coach Track and Field High School Posting 549
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach Track and Field High School Posting 549 at Los Alamos High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Coach Track and Field High School Posting 549 plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Los Alamos High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Coach Track and Field High School Posting 549 expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Coach Track and Field High School Posting 549 supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Coach Track and Field High School Posting 549 may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Los Alamos High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Head Coach Boys Basketball Middle School Posting
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Coach Boys Basketball Middle School Posting at Los Alamos Middle School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Head Coach Boys Basketball Middle School Posting is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Los Alamos Middle School, the Head Coach Boys Basketball Middle School Posting helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Head Coach Boys Basketball Middle School Posting may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Los Alamos Middle School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Head Coach Boys Basketball Middle School Posting follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.
