Job.JobTitle: Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025-2026
Job.JobDescription:
The Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025 position at Riverside High is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025 works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025 at Riverside High sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Riverside High, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025 encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025 is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025 position at Riverside High is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobTitle: Adjunct Coach Girls Distance Track Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Adjunct Coach Girls Distance Track Coach at J.L. Mann High is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Adjunct Coach Girls Distance Track Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at J.L. Mann High reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Adjunct Coach Girls Distance Track Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Adjunct Coach Girls Distance Track Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Adjunct Coach Girls Distance Track Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at J.L. Mann High. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The Varsity Football - Assistant Coaches Coach at Southside High is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Varsity Football - Assistant Coaches Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Southside High use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Varsity Football - Assistant Coaches Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Varsity Football - Assistant Coaches Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Varsity Football - Assistant Coaches Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Southside High. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The Adjunct Coach Assistant Wrestling Coach 2025 role at J.L. Mann High is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Adjunct Coach Assistant Wrestling Coach 2025 is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at J.L. Mann High are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Adjunct Coach Assistant Wrestling Coach 2025 listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Adjunct Coach Assistant Wrestling Coach 2025 encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Adjunct Coach Assistant Wrestling Coach 2025 follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At J.L. Mann High, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Adjunct Coach Assistant Wrestling Coach 2025 at J.L. Mann High, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The Adjunct Coach Track (Thrower) position at J.L. Mann High is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Adjunct Coach Track (Thrower) is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At J.L. Mann High, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Adjunct Coach Track (Thrower) encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Adjunct Coach Track (Thrower) also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Adjunct Coach Track (Thrower) role at J.L. Mann High is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head JV Girls Soccer Coach - Philip Simmons High
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head JV Girls Soccer Coach - Philip Simmons High role at Berkeley County is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head JV Girls Soccer Coach - Philip Simmons High is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Berkeley County, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head JV Girls Soccer Coach - Philip Simmons High sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Berkeley County, the 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head JV Girls Soccer Coach - Philip Simmons High is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head JV Girls Soccer Coach - Philip Simmons High at Berkeley County is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job Summary: We are seeking a dynamic, passionate, and skilled Supplemental Athletic Coach to assist in the development and coaching of student-athletes in various sports programs. This position will focus on enhancing individual and team performance, supporting the head coach, and promoting a positive and inclusive athletic environment. The Supplemental Athletic Coach will work closely with athletes, coaches, and staff to help guide students toward their full potential, both in sport and personal development.
Key Responsibilities: Assist the head coach with planning and implementing daily practice sessions, drills, and team strategies. Provide individualized coaching and support to athletes to help improve their technical skills, athletic performance, and teamwork. Foster a positive and motivating atmosphere that encourages the growth and development of all student-athletes. Evaluate athlete performance and provide constructive feedback to improve skills, strength, and conditioning. Support the organization and management of game-day operations, including warm-ups, player preparation, and team logistics. Collaborate with coaching staff to set team goals and help track progress toward those goals. Assist in the monitoring of athlete eligibility, attendance, and participation requirements. Ensure that all practices and events comply with relevant regulations, rules, and school policies. Help maintain and organize athletic equipment and ensure the safety of all participants during training and events. Serve as a mentor and role model, promoting sportsmanship, leadership, and respect for others. Communicate regularly with parents and guardians regarding athlete progress and team matters. Contribute to the recruitment of new athletes and support the retention of current team members.
Qualifications: Previous coaching experience in the relevant sport (1-3 years preferred). Knowledge of sport-specific techniques, rules, and strategies. Ability to communicate effectively with athletes, parents, staff, and administration. Strong organizational and time-management skills. A commitment to promoting a positive and inclusive team environment. CPR and First Aid certification (or willingness to obtain). High school diploma or equivalent (Bachelor’s degree in Physical Education, Sports Management, or a related field is a plus). Ability to work flexible hours, including evenings and weekends, as needed.
Desired Skills & Abilities: Strong interpersonal and motivational skills to connect with athletes. Ability to adapt coaching techniques to the needs and skill levels of individual athletes. Experience with strength and conditioning, as well as injury prevention and rehabilitation. Enthusiasm for teaching and mentoring young athletes. Knowledge of current trends in sports coaching and athlete development.
Physical Requirements: Ability to participate in physical activities such as drills, conditioning, and demonstrations. Ability to lift and carry athletic equipment and materials. Ability to stand, walk, and move around frequently during practices and games.
Working Conditions: The position may require working outside in various weather conditions. Some travel may be required for away games and tournaments.

A commitment to promoting a positive and inclusive team environment. CPR and First Aid certification (or willingness to obtain). High school diploma or equivalent (Bachelor’s degree in Physical Education, Sports Management, or a related field is a plus). Ability to work flexible hours, including evenings and weekends, as needed. Desired Skills & Abilities: Strong interpersonal and motivational skills to connect with athletes. Ability to adapt coaching techniques to the needs and skill levels of individual athletes. Experience with strength and conditioning, as well as injury prevention and rehabilitation. Enthusiasm for teaching and mentoring young athletes. Knowledge of current trends in sports coaching and athlete development. Physical Requirements: Ability to participate in physical activities such as drills, conditioning, and demonstrations. Ability to lift and carry athletic equipment and materials. Ability to stand, walk, and move around frequently during practices and games. Working Conditions: The position may require working outside in various weather conditions. Some travel may be required for away games and tournaments.

The Supplemental Coach role at KEENAN HIGH SCHOOL emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Supplemental Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At KEENAN HIGH SCHOOL, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Supplemental Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent KEENAN HIGH SCHOOL at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Supplemental Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Supplemental Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Supplemental Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at KEENAN HIGH SCHOOL.

Classification Title: Supplemental Coach Job Summary: We are seeking a dynamic, passionate, and skilled Supplemental Athletic Coach to assist in the development and coaching of student-athletes in various sports programs. This position will focus on enhancing individual and team performance, supporting the head coach, and promoting a positive and inclusive athletic environment. The Supplemental Athletic Coach will work closely with athletes, coaches, and staff to help guide students toward their full potential, both in sport and personal development. Key Responsibilities: Assist the head coach with planning and implementing daily practice sessions, drills, and team strategies. Provide individualized coaching and support to athletes to help improve their technical skills, athletic performance, and teamwork. Foster a positive and motivating atmosphere that encourages the growth and development of all student-athletes. Evaluate athlete performance and provide constructive feedback to improve skills, strength, and conditioning. Support the organization and management of game-day operations, including warm-ups, player preparation, and team logistics. Collaborate with coaching staff to set team goals and help track progress toward those goals. Assist in the monitoring of athlete eligibility, attendance, and participation requirements. Ensure that all practices and events comply with relevant regulations, rules, and school policies. Help maintain and organize athletic equipment and ensure the safety of all participants during training and events. Serve as a mentor and role model, promoting sportsmanship, leadership, and respect for others. Communicate regularly with parents and guardians regarding athlete progress and team matters. Contribute to the recruitment of new athletes and support the retention of current team members. Qualifications: Previous coaching experience in the relevant sport (1-3 years preferred). Knowledge of sport-specific techniques, rules, and strategies. Ability to communicate effectively with athletes, parents, staff, and administration. Strong organizational and time-management skills. A commitment to promoting a positive and inclusive team environment. CPR and First Aid certification (or willingness to obtain). High school diploma or equivalent (Bachelor’s degree in Physical Education, Sports Management, or a related field is a plus). Ability to work flexible hours, including evenings and weekends, as needed. Desired Skills & Abilities: Strong interpersonal and motivational skills to connect with athletes. Ability to adapt coaching techniques to the needs and skill levels of individual athletes. Experience with strength and conditioning, as well as injury prevention and rehabilitation. Enthusiasm for teaching and mentoring young athletes. Knowledge of current trends in sports coaching and athlete development. Physical Requirements: Ability to participate in physical activities such as drills, conditioning, and demonstrations. Ability to lift and carry athletic equipment and materials. Ability to stand, walk, and move around frequently during practices and games. Working Conditions: The position may require working outside in various weather conditions. Some travel may be required for away games and tournaments.

The Supplemental Coach position at LOWER RICHLAND HIGH SCHOOL provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Supplemental Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At LOWER RICHLAND HIGH SCHOOL, the Supplemental Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Supplemental Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Supplemental Coach at LOWER RICHLAND HIGH SCHOOL is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: 2026-2027 Athletic Director at Hilton Head Island High School
Job.JobDescription:
POSITION PURPOSE: To provide each enrolled student an opportunity to participate in an extracurricular athletic activity that will foster physical skills, a sense of worth and competence, a knowledge and understanding of the pleasure of sport, the principles of play, and satisfaction of being part of a team.
ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: • Organizes and administers the overall program of extracurricular athletics, both intramural and interscholastic for the assigned school. • Provides leadership in the selection, assignment, and evaluation of athletic coaches and staff members. • Fosters good school-community relations by keeping the community aware of and responsive to the athletic program. • Promotes student athletes with post-secondary educational institutions. • Assists student athletes with obtaining appropriate post-secondary educational opportunities. • Assumes responsibility for the organization and scheduling of all interscholastic athletic events. • Hires officials, team physicians, and security, as required, and assumes general responsibility for the proper supervision of home games. • Arranges transportation for athletic contest participants. • Develops and places into operation appropriate rules and regulations governing the conduct of athletic activities. • Verifies each athlete’s eligibility according to established physical and academic requirements of eligibility for participation in each sport. • Prepares and administers the athletic program budget. • Supervises all ticket sales and fund-raising events of the athletic program and assumes responsibility for proper handling of funds. • Meets and/or assists with the needs of visiting teams, such as lodging, meals, towels, gymnasium services, and field assistance, as appropriate. • Makes arrangements for non-school use of playing fields and facilities, within district guidelines. • Arranges field and gym practice schedules. • Provides for physical examination of all athletes prior to the beginning of each season. • Administers the insurance program covering school athletes and assumes responsibility for all processing of reports and claims. • Plans and supervises an annual recognition program for school athletes. • Regularly attends and represents the school at district and state meetings regarding athletics. • Assists the administration in the implementation and supervision of the district’s policies regarding student, extra-curricular participation. • Collects data and reports on student extra-curricular participation and requirements of Title IX. • Helps to maintain physical facilities and communicates needs of the school’s athletic program to school and district administration.
ADDITIONAL DUTIES: Performs other related tasks as assigned by the Principal, Superintendent or other district office administrator as designated by the Superintendent.
QUALIFICATIONS: • Must hold a South Carolina teaching and/or administrative certification. • Preference will be given to individuals with national certification in Athletic/Sports Administration. • Valid driver’s license. EXPERIENCE: • A minimum of five years of experience in coaching team sports, preferably at the high school level. • At least five years of teaching experience preferred. PHYSICAL DEMANDS: The physical demands described here are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential responsibilities and functions of the job and are not meant to be all inclusive. Reasonable accommodation may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential responsibilities and functions of the job. Unless reasonable accommodations can be made, while performing this job the staff member shall: 1. Use strength to lift items needed to perform the functions of the job. 2. Sit, stand and walk for required periods of time. 3. Speak and hear. 4. Use close vision, color vision, peripheral vision and depth perception along with the ability to focus vision. 5. Communicate effectively in English, using proper grammar and vocabulary. American Sign Language or Braille may also be considered as acceptable forms of communication. 6. Reach with hands and arms and use hands and fingers to handle objects and operate tools, technology equipment, computers, and/or controls. WORK PLACE EXPECTATIONS: 1. Work effectively with and respond to diverse cultures or backgrounds. 2. Demonstrate professionalism and appropriate judgment in behavior, speech, and dress in a neat, clean and professional manner for the assignment and work setting. 3. Have regular and punctual attendance. 4. Follow all District policies, work procedures, and reasonable requests by the proper authorities. 5. As an employee of Beaufort County School District, I am to adhere to confidentiality as directed by Federal, State and Local Laws/Regulations; and in accordance with district administrative rules as it pertains to sensitive information, employee information and student information. Failure to adhere to confidentiality may result in disciplinary actions, up to and including termination of employment.
REPORTS TO: Principal DAYS PER YEAR: 220 SALARY CLASSIFICATION: Paid on the Administrative Salary Schedule - Level 207 EMPLOYEE GROUP: Administrative APPLICATION PROCEDURES: Must apply online by completing an "Administrative" application and adding this specific job to your online application. FLSA STATUS: Exempt EMPLOYEE'S ACKNOWLEDGEMENT STATEMENT: 1. I have reviewed the above position description and understand its contents. 2. I am aware that my position description may be revised or updated at any time and once notified of changes, I remain responsible for knowledge of its contents. 3. I hereby certify that I possess the physical and mental ability to fulfill the essential functions of the above position with or without reasonable accommodation(s). If I require accommodation(s) in order to fulfill any or all of these functions, I agree to provide information to the District regarding the requested accommodation(s).
Job.Experience: A minimum of five years of experience in coaching team sports, preferably at the high school level. • At least five years of teaching experience preferred.
Job.SalaryRange: Paid on the Administrative Salary Schedule - Level 207

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Boys Basketball Coach role at ROBERT SMALLS LEADERSHIP ACAD is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Assistant Boys Basketball Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at ROBERT SMALLS LEADERSHIP ACAD are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Assistant Boys Basketball Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Assistant Boys Basketball Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Assistant Boys Basketball Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At ROBERT SMALLS LEADERSHIP ACAD, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Assistant Boys Basketball Coach at ROBERT SMALLS LEADERSHIP ACAD, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

POSITION PURPOSE: Prepares each participating student athlete for competition in sports activities, and helps them to achieve a high level of skill, an appreciation for the values of discipline and sportsmanship, and an increased level of self-esteem.
ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: • Prioritize athletics as a supplemental program to support the academic mission of the school. • Carry out the aims and objectives of the sports program as outlined by the Athletic Director and school district administration. • Instruct athletes in individual and team fundamentals, sportsmanship, cooperation, strategy and playing tactics, and physical conditioning necessary to realize individual and team success. • Assist the Athletic Director in scheduling intramural and interscholastic contests. • Assist in planning and scheduling a regular program of practice in season. • Maintain required attendance forms, insurance records, and other related documents. • Assist in oversight of safety conditions in the facility or area in which the assigned sport is conducted at all times student athletes are present. • Assist in establishing and implementing performance criteria for academic eligibility in interscholastic competition of the identified sport. • Enforce code of conduct standards and sportsmanlike behavior at all times; establish and oversee penalties for breach of standards by student athletes. • Recommend purchase of equipment, supplies, uniforms, etc. as appropriate.
ADDITIONAL DUTIES: Performs other related tasks as assigned by the Athletic Director, Principal, Superintendent or other district office administrator as designated by the Superintendent.
QUALIFICATIONS: • Previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. • Knowledge and/or background in the assigned sport. • Teaching certificate and experience preferred. • Must be able to pass criminal background check. • Valid drivers license.
EXPERIENCE: • Must have knowledge of South Carolina High School League rules and eligibility. • Must be cooperative, service-oriented, and able to work effectively with frequent interruptions. • Must possess excellent interpersonal skills. • Must have the ability to exercise good judgment, organize tasks, follow written and verbal directions, and communicate effectively.
PHYSICAL DEMANDS: The physical demands described here are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential responsibilities and functions of the job and are not meant to be all inclusive. Reasonable accommodation may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential responsibilities and functions of the job.
Unless reasonable accommodations can be made, while performing this job the staff member shall: 1. Use strength to lift items needed to perform the functions of the job. 2. Sit, stand and walk for required periods of time. 3. Speak and hear. 4. Use close vision, color vision, peripheral vision and depth perception along with the ability to focus vision. 5. Communicate effectively in English, using proper grammar and vocabulary. American Sign Language or Braille may also be considered as acceptable forms of communication. 6. Reach with hands and arms and use hands and fingers to handle objects and operate tools, technology equipment, computers, and/or controls.
WORK PLACE EXPECTATIONS: 1. Work effectively with and respond to diverse cultures or backgrounds. 2. Demonstrate professionalism and appropriate judgment in behavior, speech, and dress in a neat, clean and professional manner for the assignment and work setting. 3. Have regular and punctual attendance. 4. Follow all District policies, work procedures, and reasonable requests by the proper authorities. 5. As an employee of Beaufort County School District, I am to adhere to confidentiality as directed by Federal, State and Local Laws/Regulations; and in accordance with district administrative rules as it pertains to sensitive information, employee information and student information. Failure to adhere to confidentiality may result in disciplinary actions, up to and including termination of employment.

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: Prioritize athletics as a supplemental program to support the academic mission of the school. Carry out the aims and objectives of the sports program as outlined by the Athletic Director and school district administration. Instruct athletes in individual and team fundamentals, sportsmanship, cooperation, strategy and playing tactics, and physical conditioning necessary to realize individual and team success. Assist the Athletic Director in scheduling intramural and interscholastic contests. Assist in planning and scheduling a regular program of practice in season. Maintain required attendance forms, insurance records, and other related documents. Assist in oversight of safety conditions in the facility or area in which the assigned sport is conducted at all times student athletes are present. Assist in establishing and implementing performance criteria for academic eligibility in interscholastic competition of the identified sport. Enforce code of conduct standards and sportsmanship behavior at all times; establish and oversee penalties for breach of standards by student athletes. Recommend purchase of equipment, supplies, uniforms, etc. as appropriate.
ADDITIONAL DUTIES: Performs other related tasks as assigned by the Athletic Director, Principal, Superintendent or other district office administrator as designated by the Superintendent.
QUALIFICATIONS: Previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. Knowledge and/or background in the assigned sport. Teaching certificate and experience preferred. Must be able to pass criminal background check. Valid drivers license.
EXPERIENCE: Must have knowledge of South Carolina High School League rules and eligibility. Must be cooperative, service-oriented, and able to work effectively with frequent interruptions.

The Assistant Coach - Track and Field at MAY RIVER HIGH is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Coach - Track and Field is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At MAY RIVER HIGH, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Coach - Track and Field helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Coach - Track and Field works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at MAY RIVER HIGH operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent MAY RIVER HIGH with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Coach - Track and Field reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Coach - Track and Field role at MAY RIVER HIGH.

POSITION PURPOSE: Prepares each participating student athlete for competition in sports activities, and helps them to achieve a high level of skill, an appreciation for the values of discipline and sportsmanship, and an increased level of self-esteem.

Job.JobDescription:
The Lacrosse - Varsity Girls Assistant Coach position at Brigette McSheehan provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Lacrosse - Varsity Girls Assistant Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Brigette McSheehan, the Lacrosse - Varsity Girls Assistant Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Lacrosse - Varsity Girls Assistant Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Lacrosse - Varsity Girls Assistant Coach at Brigette McSheehan is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.
Job.Location: Nation Ford High School - Fort Mill, South Carolina

Job.JobTitle: JV Boys Lacrosse Asst. Coach - High School
Job.JobDescription:
The JV Boys Lacrosse Asst. Coach - High School role at Catawba Ridge High School - Fort Mill is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the JV Boys Lacrosse Asst. Coach - High School is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Catawba Ridge High School - Fort Mill, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The JV Boys Lacrosse Asst. Coach - High School sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Catawba Ridge High School - Fort Mill, the JV Boys Lacrosse Asst. Coach - High School is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the JV Boys Lacrosse Asst. Coach - High School at Catawba Ridge High School - Fort Mill is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobDescription:
The Girls Soccer Coach - Middle School at Gold Hill Middle School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Girls Soccer Coach - Middle School manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Gold Hill Middle School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Girls Soccer Coach - Middle School demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Girls Soccer Coach - Middle School follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Girls Soccer Coach - Middle School at Gold Hill Middle School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobTitle: Boys Track Assistant Coach - High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Boys Track Assistant Coach - High School position at Dwayne Hartsoe is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Boys Track Assistant Coach - High School works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Boys Track Assistant Coach - High School at Dwayne Hartsoe sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Dwayne Hartsoe, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Boys Track Assistant Coach - High School encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Boys Track Assistant Coach - High School is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Boys Track Assistant Coach - High School position at Dwayne Hartsoe is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.
Job.Location: Fort Mill High School - Fort Mill, South Carolina

Job.JobDescription:
The Swim - Junior Varsity Head Coach (Boys) role at Dutch Fork High School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Swim - Junior Varsity Head Coach (Boys) coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Dutch Fork High School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Swim - Junior Varsity Head Coach (Boys) reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Dutch Fork High School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Swim - Junior Varsity Head Coach (Boys) may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Swim - Junior Varsity Head Coach (Boys) monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Swim - Junior Varsity Head Coach (Boys) must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Dutch Fork High School.

The Softball - Junior Varsity Head Coach - 2025/2026 at Chapin High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Softball - Junior Varsity Head Coach - 2025/2026 plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Chapin High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Softball - Junior Varsity Head Coach - 2025/2026 expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Softball - Junior Varsity Head Coach - 2025/2026 supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Softball - Junior Varsity Head Coach - 2025/2026 may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Chapin High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

From a coaching standpoint, the Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Irmo High School, the Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Irmo High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Reports To: School Athletic Director and/or School Administration
Job Summary: Rock Hill Schools is seeking a dedicated and knowledgeable Athletic Coach to lead, motivate, and develop athletes to reach their highest potential in both skill and character. The Athletic Coach will plan and implement practice sessions, guide athletes in training and competition, promote teamwork and sportsmanship, and ensure the health and safety of all participants.
Key Responsibilities:
Develop and execute effective training programs and practice plans. Instruct athletes in the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport. Evaluate athlete performance and provide constructive feedback. Foster a positive team culture that emphasizes discipline, effort, integrity, and mutual respect. Ensure adherence to all rules and regulations set by the school, league, or governing body. Monitor the physical and mental condition of athletes, including injury prevention and first response. Coordinate with assistant coaches, athletic trainers, and other staff. Communicate regularly with athletes, parents, and administration. Attend all practices, games, meetings, and required events. Maintain equipment and inventory related to the specific sport. Serve as a role model and mentor to student-athletes.
Qualifications:
Proven coaching experience in [specific sport, e.g., basketball, soccer, track, etc.]. Knowledge of sport-specific techniques, rules, and strategies. Excellent leadership, motivational, and organizational skills. Strong interpersonal and communication abilities. Satisfactory background report
Preferred:
Experience coaching at the [high school/collegiate/professional] level. Relevant coaching certification (e.g., NFHS, USA Coaching, etc.)
Start Date: Determined by Human Resources.
PRE-ONBOARDING REQUIREMENTS: As a condition of employment and prior to onboarding, the district will conduct a criminal history background check. The recommended candidate will be required to provide personal information necessary to complete the background check such as date of birth, gender, and race to remain in compliance with applicable laws and regulations.
DISCLAIMER: The District reserves the right to modify job postings and/or job descriptions at any time to meet organizational needs.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach position at Grizzell Middle School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach at Grizzell Middle School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Grizzell Middle School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach position at Grizzell Middle School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The Assistant Softball Coach position at Grizzell Middle School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Assistant Softball Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Grizzell Middle School, the Assistant Softball Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Assistant Softball Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Assistant Softball Coach at Grizzell Middle School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role.
