The Head Mens Track Coach position at Youngstown City is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Head Mens Track Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Youngstown City, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Head Mens Track Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Head Mens Track Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Head Mens Track Coach role at Youngstown City is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The Assistant Mens Track Coach position at Youngstown City is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Assistant Mens Track Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Assistant Mens Track Coach at Youngstown City sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Youngstown City, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Assistant Mens Track Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Assistant Mens Track Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Assistant Mens Track Coach position at Youngstown City is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The Assistant Womens Track Coach role at Youngstown City emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Assistant Womens Track Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Youngstown City, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Assistant Womens Track Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Youngstown City at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Assistant Womens Track Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Assistant Womens Track Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Assistant Womens Track Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Youngstown City.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Coach - Middle School Track Coach
Head Coach - Middle School Track Coach
Job.JobDescription:
Reports to: Athletic Director and Head Coach
General Description: The position of assistant coach will be filled based upon input from the head coach, Athletic Director, and Building Principal and recommendation of the Superintendent to the Board of Education. The assistant coach must meet all provisions of the Lake Board of Education and the OHSAA.
Responsible to Athletic Director and head coach. Attend all meetings scheduled by the head coach. Assist in the administration of the athletic program. Demonstrate loyalty to the head coach and to the program. Maintain good public relations with those groups and individuals involved with the program. Support the Lake Athletic Booster Club. Assume responsibilities of head coach in matters of supervision in absence of head coach. Pre-Season responsibilities: be in attendance from the first day of practice. assist with the supervision of practices and games. assist with the issuance of equipment. assist in pre-season conditioning as assigned by the head coach. In-Season responsibilities: carry out the duties assigned by the head coach. assist the trainer with his/her duties. scout other schools' teams as necessary. observe and communicate with feeder coaches in the program. Off-season responsibilities: assist in the collection, storage, and inventory of equipment. assist with banquet activities. attend clinics when possible. assist with the off-season conditioning program. Qualifications: Must possess a valid Pupil Activity Permit (and all necessary certificates). Acts that are deemed as lude, sexual, or inappropriate will be viewed as unacceptable and may be considered as grounds for administrative action, dismissal, or termination of contract.

The incumbent will be required to follow the instructions and perform the duties required by the incumbent's supervisor, appointing authority.

Job.JobTitle: Varsity Head Volleyball Coach- Fall Supplemental
Job.JobDescription:
VACANCY NOTICE: Varsity Head Volleyball Coach LOCATION: Wooster High School
JOB SUMMARY: Wooster High School is seeking a Head Volleyball Coach to carry out the aims and objectives of the program as outlined by the athletic director and school administration. The goal is to instruct athletes in individual and team fundamentals, strategy, and physical training necessary to realize a degree of individual and team success.
QUALIFICATIONS: • Head varsity volleyball coaching experience. • Ability to communicate with coaches, parents, and athletes in an appropriate and professional manner at all times. • Can provide oversight of volleyball programs and staff grades 7-12. • Can work with youth organizations for the development of volleyball in the community. • Current Pupil Activity validation or ability to obtain prior to the beginning of the activity. • Demonstrate technical and tactical knowledge of and/or playing background in the sport of volleyball. • Ability to motivate and to challenge student-athletes in an enthusiastic and organized manner. • Has demonstrated the ability to lead a culture of high expectations in academics, discipline, and winning. • Demonstrate loyalty to the program he/she is involved with and be supportive of other coaches in this program and throughout the athletic program. • Good communication skills with administration, community, and media. • Willingness to be involved in the Wooster City School District’s overall athletic program. • Will assist in promoting athletes for college and post high school opportunities in athletics.
LEGAL REQUIREMENTS: Employees must pass a criminal background investigation and provide a fingerprint card prior to employment.
**This job description in no manner states or implies that these are the only duties and responsibilities to be performed by the position incumbent who will be required to follow other instructions and perform any duties required by the position’s supervisor(s), superintendent or his/her designee.
HOW TO APPLY: Internal Candidates: Submit APPLITRACK application by the posting deadline External Candidates: A submitted APPLITRACK application and a current resume must be received online by the posting deadline. Paper documents will not be accepted. Substitutes and General's Club Only Employees: Apply as an external candidate
Applitrack Link: http://www.applitrack.com/wooster/onlineapp or visit www.woostercityschools.org and click on Employment to navigate to all current postings
**Wooster City School District is an equal opportunity employer with a strong commitment to create and sustain a diverse, equitable, and inclusive community.

The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions.
REPORTS TO: The Athletic Director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principals
SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the Athletic Director and respective principal.
JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self discipline, self confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc.
GENERAL: 1. The success of athletic programs has a strong influence on the community's image of the entire system. The public exposure is a considerable responsibility and community/parent pressure for winning performance is taxing, but must not override the objectives of good sportsmanship and good mental health. 2. The position includes other unusual aspects such as extended time, risk injury factor and due process predicaments. 3. It is the express intent of this job description to give sufficient guidance to function. Job.JobTitle: Head Girls Track Coach-Middle School Spring Athletics 25-26 SY
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Girls Track Coach-Middle School Spring Athletics 25-26 SY role at Maple Heights City Schools is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Head Girls Track Coach-Middle School Spring Athletics 25-26 SY is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Maple Heights City Schools, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Head Girls Track Coach-Middle School Spring Athletics 25-26 SY sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Maple Heights City Schools, the Head Girls Track Coach-Middle School Spring Athletics 25-26 SY is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Head Girls Track Coach-Middle School Spring Athletics 25-26 SY at Maple Heights City Schools is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

The Head Varsity Coach-Girls Softball at Maple Heights High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Head Varsity Coach-Girls Softball is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Maple Heights High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Head Varsity Coach-Girls Softball helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Head Varsity Coach-Girls Softball works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Maple Heights High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Maple Heights High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Head Varsity Coach-Girls Softball reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Head Varsity Coach-Girls Softball role at Maple Heights High School.

Job Summary
Ross Local School District is seeking a qualified and motivated individual to serve as the Varsity Boys Head Soccer Coach at Ross High School. The Head Coach is responsible for leading and managing all aspects of the varsity boys soccer program, while promoting academic achievement, sportsmanship, and the overall development of student-athletes in alignment with district values and OHSAA regulations.
Essential Duties and Responsibilities
Plan, organize, and conduct effective practices and training sessions. Lead and supervise all varsity boys' soccer competitions. Develop and maintain a positive and safe team culture. Promote academic success, sportsmanship, and character development among student-athletes. Coordinate and collaborate with the Athletic Director, school administration, and other coaching staff. Support and help develop the overall boys soccer program, including cooperation with middle school and youth programs as appropriate. Ensure compliance with OHSAA, district policies, and league rules and regulations. Communicate effectively with players, parents, staff, and administration. Maintain accurate records, including attendance, eligibility, and equipment inventories. Supervise student-athletes before, during, and after practices and contests.
Qualifications
Demonstrated knowledge of soccer fundamentals, strategies, and rules. Previous coaching experience at the high school or competitive club level preferred. Strong leadership, organizational, and communication skills. Ability to positively motivate and mentor student-athletes. Commitment to maintaining high standards of professionalism and ethics.
Required Certifications (the district will guide you through these steps)
Valid Ohio Pupil Activity Permit Completion of all OHSAA-required coaching certifications Current CPR/AED and First Aid certification BCI and FBI background checks
Compensation
Supplemental coaching stipend per the Ross Local School District negotiated agreement.
Job.Benefits: Supplemental coaching stipend per the Ross Local School District negotiated agreement.

Job.JobDescription:
The JV Girls Soccer Coach role at HIGH SCHOOL is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the JV Girls Soccer Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at HIGH SCHOOL are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The JV Girls Soccer Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the JV Girls Soccer Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The JV Girls Soccer Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At HIGH SCHOOL, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the JV Girls Soccer Coach at HIGH SCHOOL, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

GRANVILLE EXEMPTED VILLAGE SCHOOL DISTRICT JOB DESCRIPTION
Title: ASSISTANT COACH
Reports to: Head Coach
Job Objective: Uses technical expertise to coach the assigned athletic activity.
Minimum Qualifications:
Complies with drug-free workplace rules and board policies. Relevant coaching experience. Knowledgeable about interscholastic athletic program regulations. Completion of state activity supervisory permit requirements (e.g., first aid/CPR, etc.). Meets all mandated health requirements. A record free of criminal violations that would prohibit public school employment.
NOTE: Supplemental contracts are offered to qualified certificated staff with appropriate training, knowledge, and experience. Unfilled positions may be offered to other suitable applicants meeting department of education permit requirements.
Essential Functions: The following are typical work responsibilities. A reasonable accommodation may be made to enable a qualified individual with a disability to perform essential functions.
Works with student athletes to improve personal and teamwork skills. Provides guidance and encouragement to help students benefit from participation in program activities. Upholds board policies and follows administrative guidelines/procedures. Promotes a professional image of the school district. Encourages community partnerships that enhance district programs. Promotes effective communications and assistance. Uses problem-solving techniques to tactfully address questions/concerns. Refers policy interpretation inquiries to administrative staff. Reviews procedures and schedules before the start of the season. Consults with the head coach to evaluate program needs. Promotes the proper use, care, and security of school property. Attends all mandatory programs (e.g., rules interpretation, safety clinics, etc.). Monitors innovations, evaluates activities, and recommends program improvements. Helps coordinate the development of off-season activities (e.g., summer training, clinics, etc.). Helps parents and students understand program objectives. Explains student responsibilities (e.g., scholastic eligibility, permission forms, medical exams, activity schedules, letters, awards, participation certificates, insurance coverage, waiver forms, etc.). Encourages student involvement in program activities. Helps verify medical/scholastic eligibility. Promotes academic success as an important priority for all students. Helps organize team tryouts. Helps maintain the integrity of the selection process. Carries out the assigned practice schedule. Gives the head coach a copy of all student communications. Helps ensure that all athletes receive appropriate instruction, support, and opportunities to participate. Helps assign and track equipment issued to staff and students. Helps supervise the preparation of athletic fields and practice/training areas as directed. Teaches precautions and procedures to help students prevent injuries. Ensures that equipment is appropriate for participants’ physical development and skill level. Helps ensure that all required medical authorizations forms are on file and readily available. Documents all injuries that require treatment. Helps evaluate individual/team performance. Helps develop/refine game strategies. Helps recruit, train, and supervise student managers, trainers, and scouts. Helps the activities director secure personnel for home games when requested. Upholds the student conduct code. Implements effective pupil management procedures. Models behavior that demonstrates respect for rules, officials, and opponents. Ensures that participant communications do not demean or ridicule mistakes and/or performance. Helps arrange transportation and accompanies the team to sanctioned athletic activities. Obtains permission to be away when duties conflict with other assigned duties. Provides guidance, communicates expectations, and shows an active interest in student progress. Participates in athletic recognition programs. Helps verify that participants have fulfilled all requirements for letters, awards, and/or participation certificates.

The Girls Golf - Head Coach at Mr. Matt Spellman is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Girls Golf - Head Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Mr. Matt Spellman, the Girls Golf - Head Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Girls Golf - Head Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Mr. Matt Spellman well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Girls Golf - Head Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Tipp City Schools is seeking a Middle School Baseball Coach to lead and supervise the middle school baseball program. Requirements: Applicants must meet all Ohio Department of Education (ODE) requirements for coaching, including:
Valid Ohio Pupil Activity Permit (or ability to obtain) Current BCI and FBI background checks Completion of required ODE-approved trainings (Fundamentals of Coaching, Concussion Education, Sudden Cardiac Arrest, and First Aid/CPR/AED) Knowledge of baseball fundamentals and ability to work with middle school students
Application: Apply online through the Dayton Area School Consortium: https://www.applitrack.com/dayton/onlineapp/
Questions should be directed to Kaci Matthews at kmatthews@tippcity.k12.oh.us or Kregg Creamer at kcreamer@tippcity.k12.oh.us

Job.JobTitle: High School Boys JV Golf Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The High School Boys JV Golf Coach position at Kregg Creamer is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The High School Boys JV Golf Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Kregg Creamer, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The High School Boys JV Golf Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The High School Boys JV Golf Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the High School Boys JV Golf Coach role at Kregg Creamer is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

VARSITY GIRLS GOLF COACH LEVEL C JONATHAN ALDER LOCAL SCHOOLS TITLE: Head Athletic Coach - supplemental position SUGGESTED QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Valid driver's license. 2. State of Ohio Teaching License (preferred, not required). 3. Coaching and administrative abilities. 4. Experience in related field 5. Required to maintain a valid Pupil Activity Permit Validation and all items required to obtain PAP via the Ohio Department of Education. Copies of all certifications must be on file prior to coaching. REPORTS TO: Athletic Director, Principal or Designee SALARY: Supplemental as per negotiated agreement POSITION GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self discipline, self confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc. SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal. 1.0 PROFESSIONAL & PERSONAL RELATIONSHIPS 1.01 Cooperates with the Athletic Director in regard to submitting participant lists, bus times, parent permission, physical cards, year-end reports and program information relative to your sport. 1.02 Follows policy in the Athletic Handbook and meets all criteria as outlined in the job description. 1.03 Provides training rules to team members in writing and follows due process procedures. 1.04 Develops rapport with the athletic coaching staff. 1.05 Participates in in-service meetings and other activities to improve coaching performance. Attends meetings necessary to the welfare of the Athletic Department. 1.06 Develops sound public relations. Co-operates with newspapers, radio, T.V., Booster Club, and interested spectators. Upholds the integrity of the athletic program by refraining from making negative remarks. 1.07 Maintains suitable sideline conduct at games. Expects sportsmanlike behavior to be displayed by assistant coaches and athletes toward all individuals involved with the contest (officials, workers, fans, etc.). 1.08 Serves as a role model to players, coaches and spectators in demonstrating good sportsmanship and ethical behavior at all times. 1.09 Demonstrates respect for opponents before, during and after the contest. Displays modesty in victory and graciousness in defeat. 1.10 Works cooperatively with junior high coaches in developing a coordinated program. 1.11 Works cooperatively with Athletic Director and completes duties assigned to them 2.11 Team performance consistent with quality of athletes available. 2.12 Supervision of players in the locker room, practice, field, bus and other areas. 3. RELATED COACHING RESPONSIBILITIES 3.01 Is concerned about the care of equipment, including issue, collection, inventory and storage. 3.02 Is cooperative in preparation of non-league scheduling. 3.03 Is cooperative in helping service clubs, Booster Club, Recreation Department and other organizations in their projects, which in turn relate to our athletic program. 3.04 Follows proper procedure for purchase of equipment. 3.05 Operates sport within the budget as submitted.

The Assistant Boys Tennis Coach position at Jonathan Alder High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Assistant Boys Tennis Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Assistant Boys Tennis Coach at Jonathan Alder High School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Jonathan Alder High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Assistant Boys Tennis Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Assistant Boys Tennis Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Assistant Boys Tennis Coach position at Jonathan Alder High School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

JH Track Assistant - Level E $2644-$3039 Must Obtain the Following Credentials Favorable BCI Background Check Favorable FBI Background Check CPR First Aid for Coaches/Sports Safety Training Fundamentals of Coaching Certification Concussion Training Sudden Cardiac Arrest Training Pupil Validation Permit from ODE Application must be completed to be considered.
QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program. 2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports) 3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions. REPORTS TO: The athletic director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principals SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal. JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self discipline, self confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc. GENERAL: 1. The success of athletic programs has a strong influence on the community's image of the entire system. The public exposure is a considerable responsibility and community/parent pressure for winning performance is taxing, but must not override the objectives of good sportsmanship and good mental health. 2. The position includes other unusual aspect such as extended time, risk injury factor and due process predicaments. 3. It is the express intent of this job description to give sufficient guidance to function. In cases not specifically covered, it shall be assumed that a coach shall exercise common sense and good judgment. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: 1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Schools' Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation by the entire staff of the sports program. 2. Has knowledge of existing system, state and league regulations; implements same consistently and interprets them for staff. 3. Understands the proper administrative line of command and refers all requests or grievances through proper channels. Is aware of all public/staff/departmental meetings that require attendance. STAFF RESPONSIBILITIES: 4. Established the fundamental philosophy, skills and techniques to be taught by staff. Designs conferences, clinics and staff meetings to insure staff awareness of overall program. 5. Trains and informs staff, encourages professional growth by encouraging clinic attendance according to local clinic policy. 6. Delegates specific duties, supervises implementation and, at season's end, analyzes staff effectiveness and evaluates all assistants. 7. Maintains discipline, adjusts grievances and works to increase morale and cooperation. 8. Performs such other duties which may be assigned by the athletic director/principal. ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES: 9. Assists the athletic director in scheduling, providing transportation and requirements for tournament and special sport events. 10. Assists in the necessary preparation to hold scheduled sport events or practices and adheres to scheduled facility times. Coordinates program with maintenance and school employees. 11. Provides proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment sites. 12. Advises the athletic director and recommends policy, method or procedural changes. STUDENT RESPONSIBILITIES: 13. Serves as a mentor to each athlete to promote the development and demonstration in student athletes the character traits of trustworthiness, respect, responsibility, fairness, caring, and citizenship. 14. Gives constant attention to a student athlete's grades and conduct. 15. By his/her presence at all practices games and while traveling, provides assistance, guidance and safeguards for each participant. 16. Provides training rules and any other unique regulations of the sport to each athlete who is considered a participant. 17. Initiates programs and policies concerning injuries, medical attention and emergencies. 18. Completes paperwork on all disabling athletic injuries on proper forms and submits to athletic office within 24 hours. 19. Directs student managers, assistants and statisticians. 20. Determines discipline, delineates procedures concerning due process when the enforcement of discipline is necessary and contracts parents when a student is dropped or becomes ineligible. 21. Assists athletes in their college or advanced educational selection. FINANCE AND EQUIPMENT: 22. Participates in the budgeting function with the athletic director by establishing requirements for the next season. Recommends equipment guidelines as to type, style, color or technical specifications. Is responsible for operating within budget appropriations. 23. Is accountable for all equipment and collects the cost of any equipment lost or not returned. Arranges for issuing, storing and reconditioning of equipment and submits annual inventory and current records concerning same. 24. Properly marks and identifies all equipment before issuing or storing. 25. Monitors equipment rooms and coaches' offices, authorizes who may enter, issue or requisition equipment. 26. Permits the athletes to only be in authorized areas of the building at the appropriate times. 27. Examines locker rooms before and after practices and games, checking on general cleanliness of the facility. Responsible for cleanliness and maintenance of specific sport equipment. 28. Secures all doors, lights, windows and locks before leaving building if custodians are not on duty. 29. Instills in each player a respect for equipment and school property, its care and proper use. PUBLIC RELATIONS: 30. Organizes parents, coaches, players and guests for preseason meetings. 31. Promotes the sport within the school through recruiting athletes who are not in another sports program and promotes the sport outside the school through news media, little league programs, or in any other feasible manner. 32. Responsible for the quality, effectiveness and validity of any oral or written release to local media. 33. Responsible for maintaining good public relations with news media, booster club, parents, officials, volunteers and fans. 34. Presents information to news media concerning schedules, tournaments and results.

HEAD VOLLEYBALL COACH – POSITION POSTING Indian Hill Exempted Village School District To Apply: Email Brian Phelps, Athletic Director, with a resume and letter of interest. POSITION: Head Volleyball Coach LOCATION: Indian Hill High School STARTING DATE: Spring 2026 Season CATEGORY: Supplemental REPORTS TO: Athletic Director STATUS: FLSA Exempt; Section 3319.02 – ORC GENERAL DESCRIPTION Indian Hill High School is ready to welcome an inspiring leader to take the helm of a volleyball program bursting with potential, energy, and pride. Our student-athletes are competitive, committed, and hungry to grow — and they thrive in a district where excellence isn’t just encouraged, it’s expected. As the Head Volleyball Coach, you’ll shape a program that blends high-level skill development with culture-building, leadership, and the kind of team chemistry that makes something magical happen on and off the court. This is your chance to build a marquee volleyball experience in one of Ohio’s most admired school districts — a place where families are supportive, the athletic department is collaborative, and student-athletes buy in fully to the vision of a coach who leads with purpose. From practice strategy to game-day intensity, you’ll have the opportunity to elevate the entire program and create moments that athletes and fans will remember for years. If fueling competitive success, developing strong young leaders, and building a program rooted in heart, grit, and high expectations excites you — Indian Hill is ready for you to lead the charge. Indian Hill High School is a high-achieving Division II athletic program serving approximately 650 students in grades 9–12. Candidates must possess all required Ohio Department of Education coaching credentials and successfully complete FBI/BCI background checks. PREFERRED SKILLS • Prior volleyball coaching experience preferred • Understanding of systems, player development, and strategy • Ability to build positive team culture

Job.JobDescription:
The Volunteer Coach - Club Lacrosse Program position at Licking Valley Local provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Volunteer Coach - Club Lacrosse Program prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Licking Valley Local, the Volunteer Coach - Club Lacrosse Program works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Volunteer Coach - Club Lacrosse Program encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Volunteer Coach - Club Lacrosse Program at Licking Valley Local is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The Varsity Boys Golf - Head Coach at Trey Newberry is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Varsity Boys Golf - Head Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Trey Newberry, the Varsity Boys Golf - Head Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Varsity Boys Golf - Head Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Trey Newberry well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Varsity Boys Golf - Head Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.
Job.CompanyDescription: New Richmond Exempted Village coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Varsity Softball Coach at Trey Newberry is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Varsity Softball Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Trey Newberry, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Varsity Softball Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Varsity Softball Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Varsity Softball Coach at Trey Newberry allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

The Anticipated Golf Assistant Coach at Red Land High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Anticipated Golf Assistant Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Red Land High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Anticipated Golf Assistant Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Anticipated Golf Assistant Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Anticipated Golf Assistant Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Red Land High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The 7th and 8th Grade Baseball Coaches may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Mr. David Lloyd well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The 7th and 8th Grade Baseball Coaches follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription:
The 7th Grade Softball Coach role at Lower Merion School District emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the 7th Grade Softball Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Lower Merion School District, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The 7th Grade Softball Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Lower Merion School District at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The 7th Grade Softball Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The 7th Grade Softball Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The 7th Grade Softball Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Lower Merion School District.

Job.JobDescription:
The Track and Field Coaches at David Lloyd is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Track and Field Coaches plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at David Lloyd reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Track and Field Coaches expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Track and Field Coaches supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Track and Field Coaches may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at David Lloyd. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobDescription:
The 7th Grade Boys Lacrosse Coach role at David Lloyd is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the 7th Grade Boys Lacrosse Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at David Lloyd are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The 7th Grade Boys Lacrosse Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the 7th Grade Boys Lacrosse Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The 7th Grade Boys Lacrosse Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At David Lloyd, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the 7th Grade Boys Lacrosse Coach at David Lloyd, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The Aquarettes Advisor at Senior High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Aquarettes Advisor is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Senior High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Aquarettes Advisor helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Aquarettes Advisor works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Senior High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Senior High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Aquarettes Advisor reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Aquarettes Advisor role at Senior High School.

The Assistant Boys Soccer Coaches (2) - PWHS at Plymouth Whitemarsh High School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Assistant Boys Soccer Coaches (2) - PWHS manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Plymouth Whitemarsh High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Assistant Boys Soccer Coaches (2) - PWHS demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Assistant Boys Soccer Coaches (2) - PWHS follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Assistant Boys Soccer Coaches (2) - PWHS at Plymouth Whitemarsh High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobDescription:
The Ultimate Frisbee Coach - PWHS role at Colonial is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Ultimate Frisbee Coach - PWHS is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Colonial, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Ultimate Frisbee Coach - PWHS sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Colonial, the Ultimate Frisbee Coach - PWHS is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Ultimate Frisbee Coach - PWHS at Colonial is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: First Aid Responder - Colonial Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
Position: First Aid Responder
Location: Colonial Middle School
The First Aid Responder provides immediate medical care and attention to students, athletes, and staff during school events and activities. This role involves assessing injuries, administering first aid, and coordinating with emergency services when necessary. The responder ensures compliance with school safety policies and maintains accurate records of incidents to support the well-being of all participants. Coverage typically includes home games and practices from 3:00 PM to 5:00 PM.
If interested, please complete the on-line application and contact Christopher Lashley @ clashley@colonialsd.org or 610-275-5100 x7914 with any questions.
Applications must be submitted on-line, we do not accept e-mails or paper applications.
Deadline: Until Filled Position Type: Part-Time
