Effective Date(s): March 9, 2026 - June 6, 2026 Staff Needed: One (1) Strength and Conditioning Coach Qualifications: * DOE Certification Requirements (including volunteer coaches) must have one of the two certifications: o New Jersey Teacher’s Certification o New Jersey Instructional Substitute Credential (30 College Credits) * Proof of experience required for Substitute Certificate holder. * Coaching experience preferred but not required. * Must be available daily during the winter sports season. * All coaches must hold a current (valid) adult CPR/AED and Basic First Aid Certification. * All courses that the DOE approves for certification are acceptable. * All new coaches (starting 2007-2008 school year) must complete the NFHS Fundamentals of Coaching Course before their first employment as a coach. This course is a one-time requirement. * All coaches must complete the NFHS Concussion in Sports Course, renewed annually. * All coaches must complete the NFHS Heat Illness Prevention Course, renewed annually. * All coaches must complete the NFHS Implicit Bias Course. This course is a one-time requirement. * All coaches must complete the BeNice Program. This course is a one-time requirement.

Hill, Athletic Supervisor * Meet such alternatives to the above qualifications as the Superintendent may find appropriate and acceptable. * Pending budget availability. * All postings are open for ten (10) consecutive days following the date posted or until filled.

The Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball role at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At John F. Kennedy Memorial High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The Anticipated Head Coach - Football at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Anticipated Head Coach - Football is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At John F. Kennedy Memorial High School, the Anticipated Head Coach - Football helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Anticipated Head Coach - Football may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents John F. Kennedy Memorial High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Anticipated Head Coach - Football follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Has knowledge of existing system and State and NMAA regulations. 2. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Roswell Independent School District Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation. 3. Has knowledge of the existing system, state and league regulations and implements them consistently. 4. Maintains discipline and works to increase morale and cooperate within the school sports program. 5. Recommends to the head coach budgetary items for next year in his area of the program. 6. Job.JobTitle: Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School at Los Lunas Public Schools is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Los Lunas Public Schools, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Los Lunas Public Schools operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Los Lunas Public Schools with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School role at Los Lunas Public Schools.
Job.Location: VHS Athletics - Los Lunas, New Mexico
Job.CompanyDescription: Los Lunas Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The VMS Track Coach 25-26 at Los Lunas Public Schools is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the VMS Track Coach 25-26 plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Los Lunas Public Schools reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The VMS Track Coach 25-26 expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the VMS Track Coach 25-26 supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the VMS Track Coach 25-26 may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Los Lunas Public Schools. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.
Job.CompanyDescription: Los Lunas Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
BEGINNING DATE: 25/26 Season
SALARY: $3,300 APPLICATION: IN-DISTRICT: Letter of interest through School Spring - Applicant Tracking. OUT-OF-DISTRICT: Complete application through the School Spring - Applicant Tracking APPLICATION DEADLINE: UNTIL FILLED QUALIFICATIONS: Applicants must have a coaching license or a coaching application with results from the NMAA to apply for their coaching license and a complete application on file.
JOB SUMMARY: To prepare athletes for competition. Participation opportunities are offered at the Varsity, Junior Varsity, 'C' Team, 9th-grade, 8th-grade, and 7th-grade levels of competition for many of the sponsored sports.
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Teaching sports techniques, playing rules, strategies, and playing tactics. Conditioning athletes appropriately for activities requiring endurance, strength, and agility. Supervising and conducting practices and contests safely; supervising locker rooms and buses. Teaching sportsmanship, cooperation, work ethic, and responsibility to one's team. Monitoring athletes' school attendance, grades, and personal conduct. Responding to player injuries with approved first aid techniques. Managing uniforms, equipment, and school facilities in a responsible manner. If Major sports course is offered- Expected to actively participate in offseason program development and implementation, including strength and conditioning, skill development, and team activities. Involvement with the school's major sport athletic class during the academic day is required.
SPECIAL CONDITIONS: Vacancies for coaching positions are developed at each school and forwarded to the Associate Superintendent of Human Resources for posting in schools. Candidates for coaching positions are screened and interviewed by the high school athletic director and/or principal. To apply for a coaching job, candidates submit a letter of interest to the office of Human Resources. The athletic director will review all candidate backgrounds and recommend candidates to be interviewed.
SALARY: Coaching salaries vary depending on the coaching assignment and the level of competition (Freshman, Sophomore, JV, or Varsity). Applicants should list related playing or coaching experiences and any training completed. In addition, candidates should list the sports they feel most comfortable teaching/coaching. (List sports in order of capability.) For further information, interested persons should call the Deming Public Schools Director of Activities and Athletics at 575-546-8126.
Revised January 2026

The Wappingers Central School District is seeking coaching applicants for a variety of openings for the 2025-26 school year.
Salary is based on the WCT Contractual coaching rates.
All applicants must have a valid fingerprint report from NYS, current Sports First Aid & CPR certifications and a current NYS sport-specific coaching license.
To apply upload your resume, a cover letter and 3 letters of recommendation (written and dated within the past 18 months by a non-WCSD employee and signed by the author. Blank or computer-generated signatures are not acceptable).
Job Qualifications Fingerprint clearance through NYS TEACH Valid NYS Coaching License
Application Procedure NYSED Fingerprint Clearance is required.
Job.SalaryRange: Salary is based on the WCT Contractual coaching rates.

Job.JobDescription:
The Head JV Girls Golf Coach at Jay Schwanke is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Head JV Girls Golf Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Jay Schwanke, the Head JV Girls Golf Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Head JV Girls Golf Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Jay Schwanke well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Head JV Girls Golf Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

The Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach position at John Bernans is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach at John Bernans sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At John Bernans, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach position at John Bernans is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The Head JV Softball Coach position at Jay Schwanke is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Head JV Softball Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Jay Schwanke, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Head JV Softball Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Head JV Softball Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Head JV Softball Coach role at Jay Schwanke is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The Head Boys Lacrosse Coach position at Jay Ohlinger provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Head Boys Lacrosse Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Jay Ohlinger, the Head Boys Lacrosse Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Head Boys Lacrosse Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Head Boys Lacrosse Coach at Jay Ohlinger is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Head Boys Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Boys Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season at Eversole Run Middle School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Head Boys Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Eversole Run Middle School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Head Boys Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Head Boys Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Head Boys Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Eversole Run Middle School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Head Girls Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Girls Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season role at Eversole Run Middle School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Head Girls Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Eversole Run Middle School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. The Head Girls Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Head Girls Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Head Girls Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Head Girls Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season at Eversole Run Middle School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The Head Football Coach role at Eversole Run Middle School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Head Football Coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Eversole Run Middle School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Head Football Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Eversole Run Middle School, the Head Football Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Head Football Coach at Eversole Run Middle School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

The Head Softball Coach at Grizzell Middle School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Head Softball Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Grizzell Middle School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Head Softball Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Head Softball Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Head Softball Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Grizzell Middle School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The Head JV Girls Tennis Coach position at Jay Schwanke is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Head JV Girls Tennis Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Head JV Girls Tennis Coach at Jay Schwanke sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Jay Schwanke, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Head JV Girls Tennis Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Head JV Girls Tennis Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Head JV Girls Tennis Coach position at Jay Schwanke is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobTitle: Coaching - HS Varsity Asst. Softball Coach
Job.JobDescription:
Job Responsibilities:
Assist the Varsity Head Coach with the Girls Softball Program. Assist with developing and training student-athletes to participate in play softball. Assist with the development and execution of an effective training program. Monitor, motivate, supervise, and mentor student-athletes on and off the Field. Ensure the safety and well-being of student-athletes. Instruct and guide student-athletes in fundamental skills, strategies, and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. Instruct and guild student-athletes to lead them to the formulation and enhancement of moral values, pride of accomplishment, acceptable social behavior, self-discipline, and self-confidence. Foster teamwork, sportsmanship, and skills development.
Job.Location: James N Gamble Montessori HS - CINCINNATI, Ohio
Job.CompanyDescription: Cincinnati City School District coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Coaching - Junior High Asst. Baseball Coach
Job.JobDescription:
Job Responsibilities:
Assist with the Junior High Baseball Program. Assist with developing and training student-athletes to play baseball. Assist with the execution and development of an effective training program. Monitor, motivate, supervise, and mentor student-athletes on and off the Field. Ensure the safety and well-being of student-athletes. Instruct and guide student-athletes in fundamental skills, strategies, and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. Instruct and guild student-athletes to lead them to the formulation and enhancement of moral values, pride of accomplishment, acceptable social behavior, self-discipline, and self-confidence. Foster teamwork, sportsmanship, and skills development. Meet all requirements set forth by the State Board of Education, CPS, the Ohio High School Athletic Association (OHSAA), and The Ohio Department of Education (ODE) relative to the mandated Coaches Tool Chest (CTC) and ODE Pupil Activity Permit (PAP). Recognize the need to be aware of and implement all applicable administrative policies set forth by the Board of Education, Superintendents of Schools, School Principals, Conference Leagues, OHSAA. Provide all applicable in-season training rules as well as any that may apply to out-of-season conduct to team members in writing prior to the start of the season. Follow appropriate due process procedures when violations occur. Model the behavior expected of our student-athletes including timeliness to games and practices, being positive and enthusiastic, being respectful, and practicing constructive criticism while upholding the disciplines of the program. Be appropriately dressed at all times. Maintain suitable sideline conduct, including the use of appropriate language, at all times. Accept and profit from constructive criticism and suggestions for improving coaching performance. Participate in clinics and other available programs to improve coaching performance. Participate in School Events (i.e., Awards Night Programs, Pep Assemblies, Athletic Boosters Meetings, etc.). Show physical vitality for the sport as well as use of good judgement and decision-making. Be competent in techniques of the sport so that student-athletes respond positively to directions given. Demonstrate the ability to adapt properly to changing game situations. Be well-versed and knowledgeable in matters pertaining to the sport and look at ways to constantly improve knowledge and coaching techniques. Be innovative in using new coaching techniques and ideas in addition to already proven methods of coaching. Ensure that team is well-prepared for opponents. Maintain accurate inventory of equipment and supplies.
Skills/Essential Functions:
Fundraising experience. Previous experience coaching baseball required. Have a passion and dedication to motivate and inspire student-athletes. Ability to serve as a positive role model. Demonstrated knowledge of skills associated with this sport. Ability to work effectively in a multicultural environment.
Training/Certifications:
Ohio Secondary Teaching Certificate preferred. Successful participation in a similar activity in high school and/or college. Provide a satisfactory result on a County Police Records Check, State BCII Check, and FBI Fingerprint Background Check. Possess an Ohio Department of Education (ODE) Pupils Activity Permit (PAP). Provide proof of completion of Coaches Tool Chest (CTC) Training/Certification
Contract Provisions:
Job.Location: James N Gamble Montessori HS - CINCINNATI, Ohio
Job.CompanyDescription: Cincinnati City School District coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Volleyball Coach Assistant (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position ***2026-2027
Job.JobDescription:
The Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Volleyball Coach Assistant (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 at Lebanon Junior High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Volleyball Coach Assistant (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Lebanon Junior High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Volleyball Coach Assistant (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Volleyball Coach Assistant (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Lebanon Junior High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Lebanon Junior High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Volleyball Coach Assistant (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Volleyball Coach Assistant (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 role at Lebanon Junior High School.

The Volleyball Coach JV-Boys at New Albany High School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Volleyball Coach JV-Boys manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At New Albany High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Volleyball Coach JV-Boys demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Volleyball Coach JV-Boys follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Volleyball Coach JV-Boys at New Albany High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.
Job.SalaryRange: Salary based on experience on Supplemental Salary Schedule

Job.JobTitle: Head Boys Tennis Coach - Ida B. Wells HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics
Job.JobDescription:
Position Details Portland Public Schools (PPS) is seeking talented people from diverse backgrounds and experiences to lead change and inspire PPS students. At PPS, every employee, despite having different roles, is an educator. We hope to attract talented educators who model the core PPS Educator Essentials. With the District’s focus on eliminating systemic racism and its adverse impact on student learning, we seek to hire individuals who bring to our district a deep commitment to racial equity and social justice.
The District is committed to equal opportunity and nondiscrimination in all its educational and employment activities. The District prohibits discrimination based on perceived or actual race; national or ethnic origin; color; sex; religion; age; sexual orientation; gender expression or identity; pregnancy; marital status; veteran’s status; familial status; economic status or source of income; mental or physical disability or perceived disability; or military service.

Accessibility Statement
Conflict/Complaint Resolution Process
DISTRICT MISSION:
At PPS, our goal is that by the end of elementary, middle and high school every student by name is meeting or exceeding academic standards and is fully prepared to make productive life decisions.
DISTRICT PROFILE:
To obtain more information about our district, schools, learning environment and programs, please go to https://www.pps.net/Domain/265.
Key points of the job description for a Varsity Head Coach:
High ethical and professional standards. Direct a successful grade 9-12 program and oversee all facets of an entire community youth program. 3 years of High School coaching experience Be a role model for high school student-athletes. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports by encouraging student-athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program. Lead student-athletes in the support of other Portland Public Schools athletics and activities.
The Head Coach will be responsible for the following:
Manage all aspects of the high school program including training, practice schedules and routines. Hire and oversee a staff of assistant coaches Provide regular communication with parents/families Regularly track the academic progress of all student athletes in the program and facilitate necessary supports to ensure their academic eligibility. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports and encourage athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program for athletics.
All new hired coaches will need to complete the following prior to employment:
NFHS/ASEP Certification First Aid Card (CPR and AED trained) District Fingerprinting/Criminal check Completion of OSAA Concussion Test Completion of ODE Steroid Test Completion of OSAA Heat Test *Head Up Football *Cheer and Dance/Drill Spirit Safety Training Completion of Portland Public School District paperwork and trainings.
Applicant will be asked to apply online at our website and include the following:
A cover letter detailing your experience. A current resume. A minimum of three letters of recommendation/reference.
All PPS job offers are contingent on the satisfactory completion of a background check, including fingerprinting and criminal records.
Salary Range - $6100.00 to $10,000.00
* There is no compensation for summer and out of season workouts.

Job.JobTitle: Softball - Assistant Coach, Sprague High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Softball - Assistant Coach, Sprague High School role at SPRAGUE HIGH SCHOOL is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Softball - Assistant Coach, Sprague High School is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at SPRAGUE HIGH SCHOOL are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Softball - Assistant Coach, Sprague High School listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Softball - Assistant Coach, Sprague High School encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Softball - Assistant Coach, Sprague High School follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At SPRAGUE HIGH SCHOOL, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Softball - Assistant Coach, Sprague High School at SPRAGUE HIGH SCHOOL, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Wrestling - Assistant Coach, Stephens Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
The Wrestling - Assistant Coach, Stephens Middle School role at STEPHENS MIDDLE SCHOOL is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Wrestling - Assistant Coach, Stephens Middle School is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At STEPHENS MIDDLE SCHOOL, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Wrestling - Assistant Coach, Stephens Middle School sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At STEPHENS MIDDLE SCHOOL, the Wrestling - Assistant Coach, Stephens Middle School is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Wrestling - Assistant Coach, Stephens Middle School at STEPHENS MIDDLE SCHOOL is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Head Boys Volleyball Coach - E698SY2526 HILLSBORO SD 1J Century High School - Hillsboro, Oregon Open in Google Maps Job Details Job ID:5409998 Application Deadline:Posted until filled Re-Posted:Jan 05, 2026 8:00 AM (UTC)
Starting Date:Immediately
Job Description
E698SY2526 | Head Boys Volleyball Coach | Century High School | Reposted Until Filled
GENERAL DUTIES:
Support the Hillsboro School District athletic objective, policy of interscholastic athletics, and Hillsboro School District Athletic Code. The District believes that extra-curricular activities are an integral part of school life. All students, regardless of their ability, should take part if possible to be able to grow physically, intellectually, and socially through participation. Coaches organize and conduct the athletic programs to meet the needs of the school district and their participants.
ESSENTIAL REQUIREMENTS:
Experience in and/or knowledge of the sport, coaching techniques, and student supervision. Ability and willingness to effectively communicate in verbal and written modes with student/athletes, parents, assistant coaches, and other school staff. Ability and willingness to perform coaching responsibilities in accordance with school and District procedures and policies. Must have current CPR/First Aid certification. Must have current Concussion Management and other trainings required by the OSAA. Maintain integrity of confidential information relating to students, staff, or District patrons. The ability to work harmoniously with others and collaborate solutions to concerns. Successfully pass background check.
To view the full job description please visit the following link: Head Coach

Job.JobTitle: 1.0 FTE Boy's Tennis Head Coach - Caldera High School - Regular
Job.JobDescription:
Bend-La Pine Schools is committed to the principle of equity. Equity supersedes the notion of equality, where all are treated the same. Pursuing equity requires the removal of barriers and the promotion of inclusive practices so that all students fully benefit. The principle of equity will inform all BLS policies, regulations, programs, operations, practices, and resource allocations. Our goal is to find the best candidate for the position, and we acknowledge that candidate may be an individual from a less traditional background. We encourage you to apply, even if you don't believe you meet every one of our qualifications described. If you are unsure whether you meet the qualifications of a position, or how this would be determined, please feel free to contact Human Resources to discuss your application.
As you prepare to submit your application for employment, please note that all consideration of experience for the position and initial salary placements will be based upon the information you submit with your original application. Resumes must be detailed and verifiable for successful experience credit, any information provided to Bend-La Pine Schools at a later date will not be the basis for adjustments in salary placement.
Bend La Pine Schools Head Coaching Details
Applicant must submit: 1. Letter of application detailing experience. 2. Current Resume – listing experience related to this position and working with students. 3. A minimum of three letters of recommendation. 4. A minimum of three references with contact information.
General Job Qualifications and Key Responsibilities of the Head Coach:
Hold high ethical and professional standards. Be an appropriate role model for high school student-athletes. Hold high expectations and accountability academically and behaviorallyfor all student-athletes and coaching staff. Ability to develop, articulate, and implement a vision for program. Ability to work in a cooperative and harmonious manner in an educationally based, school-wide athletic program. Experience leading a comprehensive high school athletic program preferred. Be relationship/process oriented. Understand and provide information regarding eligibility, tryout process, cut process, and all other team-related information to include lettering, team rules, etc. Be creative and involved in all fundraising for the program. Communicate effectively with ALL stakeholders. Be an advocate for the multi-sport athlete.
Job.Location: Caldera High School, 60925 SE 15th Street, Bend, OR, 97702, United States
Job.Experience: Experience leading a comprehensive high school athletic program preferred

Job.JobTitle: 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract – PMS - Head Coach - Football
Job.JobDescription:
The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract – PMS - Head Coach - Football position at PEIRCE MIDDLE SCHOOL is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract – PMS - Head Coach - Football is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At PEIRCE MIDDLE SCHOOL, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract – PMS - Head Coach - Football encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract – PMS - Head Coach - Football also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract – PMS - Head Coach - Football role at PEIRCE MIDDLE SCHOOL is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract – PMS - HEAD Coach - Girls Soccer
Job.JobDescription:
The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract – PMS - HEAD Coach - Girls Soccer at PEIRCE MIDDLE SCHOOL is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract – PMS - HEAD Coach - Girls Soccer is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At PEIRCE MIDDLE SCHOOL, the 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract – PMS - HEAD Coach - Girls Soccer helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract – PMS - HEAD Coach - Girls Soccer may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents PEIRCE MIDDLE SCHOOL well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract – PMS - HEAD Coach - Girls Soccer follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription: Position Summary The Head Coach for Girls Flag Football is responsible for leading and developing a competitive, educationally grounded, and character-driven athletic program at Erie High School. The Head Coach will foster positive communication and collaboration among Erie Public Schools, student-athletes, families, and community partners. This individual is expected to promote academic excellence, sportsmanship, and good citizenship while serving as a positive role model and mentor in alignment with PIAA Girls Flag Football standards. Term of Employment Seasonal � PIAA Sanctioned Sport 12-month position School / Location: Erie High School Reporting Relationships: Reports directly to the Director of Athletics and the Building Principal. Qualifications - Prior coaching experience in Girls Flag Football, football, or a related sport preferred - Thorough knowledge of PIAA bylaws and NFHS Girls Flag Football rules - Demonstrated ability to plan and implement effective practice plans and competitive strategies - Strong organizational, leadership, and communication skills - Ability to motivate, mentor, and develop student-athletes both athletically and academically - Experience working with urban student populations preferred - Ability to support and transition student-athletes to the next competitive level - Working knowledge of Erie Public Schools policies and procedures - Must obtain and maintain required FBI, PA Criminal, and Child Abuse Clearances PIAA / NFHS Compliance & Expectations The Head Coach must demonstrate a thorough understanding of and strict adherence to all Pennsylvania Interscholastic Athletic Association (PIAA) bylaws, policies, and regulations, as well as all National Federation of State High School Associations (NFHS) Girls Flag Football rules. The Head Coach is responsible for ensuring that all aspects of the Girls Flag Football program�including practices, competitions, athlete eligibility, conduct, safety protocols, and coaching behavior�are fully compliant with PIAA, NFHS, and Erie Public Schools requirements. The Head Coach must: - Maintain current knowledge of PIAA bylaws and NFHS rule updates - Complete all required PIAA, PDE, and NFHS coaching education and sport-specific certifications - Enforce rules related to eligibility, transfers, practice limitations, and seasons of participation - Model and promote sportsmanship and ethical conduct in accordance with NFHS standards - Ensure student-athlete safety through proper supervision and adherence to NFHS safety guidelines - Cooperate fully with the Athletic Director and Building Principal on all compliance matters Failure to comply with PIAA or NFHS regulations may result in disciplinary action, up to and including removal from coaching duties. Essential Duties and Responsibilities - Supervise and instruct student-athletes in compliance with PIAA and NFHS regulations - Plan, organize, and conduct practices, games, and competitions - Monitor and support academic eligibility, attendance, and conduct of student-athletes - Ensure all athletes are properly cleared, rostered, and eligible - Maintain accurate records, inventories, and equipment control - Ensure all uniforms and equipment are accounted for prior to stipend disbursement - Communicate effectively with athletes, families, and District administration - Promote safety, sportsmanship, leadership, and positive character development Off-Season Responsibilities - Participate in and support program fundraisers, as applicable - Attend or organize off-season camps, leagues, and development opportunities - Organize and supervise off-season open gym and weight room sessions - Develop off-season practice plans and instructional programming Professional Expectations The Head Coach will represent Erie Public Schools with the highest standards of professionalism, ethical conduct, and integrity at all times. Other Duties - Attend staff meetings, clinics, and professional development activities - Perform other related duties as assigned by the Athletic Director, Building Principal, or other administrator Evaluation Performance will be evaluated by the Director of Athletics and/or the Building Principal. This list intended to be illustrative rather than complete and serves to show major duties and responsibilities and does not express or imply that these are the only duties performed by the incumbent in this position. The employee will be required to perform any other position-related duties requested by the supervisor.
Job.Experience: Prior coaching experience in Girls Flag Football, football, or a related sport preferred

The Varsity Assistant Baseball Coach at Manheim Township is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Manheim Township use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. Within the school, the Varsity Assistant Baseball Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Varsity Assistant Baseball Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Manheim Township. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.
