Job.JobDescription:
The Varsity Football - Assistant Adjunct Coach at Southside High is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Varsity Football - Assistant Adjunct Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Southside High reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Varsity Football - Assistant Adjunct Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Varsity Football - Assistant Adjunct Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Varsity Football - Assistant Adjunct Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Southside High. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Boys Volleyball JV Assistant Coach - High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Boys Volleyball JV Assistant Coach - High School role at Brigette McSheehan emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Boys Volleyball JV Assistant Coach - High School coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Brigette McSheehan, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Boys Volleyball JV Assistant Coach - High School reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Brigette McSheehan at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Boys Volleyball JV Assistant Coach - High School may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Boys Volleyball JV Assistant Coach - High School monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Boys Volleyball JV Assistant Coach - High School must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Brigette McSheehan.
Job.Location: Nation Ford High School - Fort Mill, South Carolina

Job.JobDescription:
The Girls' Soccer Coach - Middle School at Springfield Middle School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Girls' Soccer Coach - Middle School is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Springfield Middle School, the Girls' Soccer Coach - Middle School helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Girls' Soccer Coach - Middle School may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Springfield Middle School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Girls' Soccer Coach - Middle School follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

The Soccer - Varsity Assistant Coach (Girls) -2026 position at School District Five of Lexington and Richland Counties is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Soccer - Varsity Assistant Coach (Girls) -2026 is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At School District Five of Lexington and Richland Counties, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Soccer - Varsity Assistant Coach (Girls) -2026 encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Soccer - Varsity Assistant Coach (Girls) -2026 also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Soccer - Varsity Assistant Coach (Girls) -2026 role at School District Five of Lexington and Richland Counties is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.
Job.EmployerFullName: School District Five of Lexington and Richland Counties

Job.JobDescription:
The Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach - 2026 at Dutch Fork High School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach - 2026 manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Dutch Fork High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach - 2026 demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach - 2026 follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach - 2026 at Dutch Fork High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

The Assistant Athletic Director position at Chapin High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Assistant Athletic Director is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Chapin High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Assistant Athletic Director encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Assistant Athletic Director also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Assistant Athletic Director role at Chapin High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Reports To: School Athletic Director and/or School Administration Job Summary: Rock Hill Schools is seeking a dedicated and knowledgeable Athletic Coach to lead, motivate, and develop athletes to reach their highest potential in both skill and character. The Athletic Coach will plan and implement practice sessions, guide athletes in training and competition, promote teamwork and sportsmanship, and ensure the health and safety of all participants. Key Responsibilities: Develop and execute effective training programs and practice plans. Instruct athletes in the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport. Evaluate athlete performance and provide constructive feedback. Foster a positive team culture that emphasizes discipline, effort, integrity, and mutual respect. Ensure adherence to all rules and regulations set by the school, league, or governing body. Monitor the physical and mental condition of athletes, including injury prevention and first response. Coordinate with assistant coaches, athletic trainers, and other staff. Communicate regularly with athletes, parents, and administration. Attend all practices, games, meetings, and required events. Maintain equipment and inventory related to the specific sport. Serve as a role model and mentor to student-athletes. Qualifications: Proven coaching experience in [specific sport, e.g., basketball, soccer, track, etc.]. Knowledge of sport-specific techniques, rules, and strategies. Excellent leadership, motivational, and organizational skills. Strong interpersonal and communication abilities. Satisfactory background report Preferred: Experience coaching at the [high school/collegiate/professional] level. Relevant coaching certification (e.g., NFHS, USA Coaching, etc.) Start Date: Determined by Human Resources. PRE-ONBOARDING REQUIREMENTS: As a condition of employment and prior to onboarding, the district will conduct a criminal history background check. The recommended candidate will be required to provide personal information necessary to complete the background check such as date of birth, gender, and race to remain in compliance with applicable laws and regulations. DISCLAIMER: The District reserves the right to modify job postings and/or job descriptions at any time to meet organizational needs. EEOC STATEMENT: Rock Hill Schools provides equal employment opportunities to all employees and applicants for employment and prohibits discrimination and harassment of any type without regard to race, color, religion, age, sex, national origin, disability status, genetics, protected veteran status, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, or any other characteristic protected by federal, state, or local laws. This policy applies to all terms and conditions of employment, including recruiting, hiring, placement, promotion, termination, layoff, recall, transfer, leaves of absence, compensation, and training. Position Type: Seasonal Job Categories: Athletics & Activities > Coaching

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - C-Team Softball (2 positions)
Job.JobDescription:
Position Type: Athletics/Activities/Athletic Coach - High School Softball Date Posted: 1/14/2026 Location: Gallup High School Date Available: 2025-2026 Closing Date: Until Filled
Title: Athletic Coach � C Team Softball Work Location: Gallup High School Contract Length: Spring Sports Minimum Salary: $4,500.00 Maximum Salary: $4,500.00
*Internal applicants MUST attach a signed Permission to Coach Form to application*
ATHLETIC COACHING LICENSE, 5-12
Must hold or have the ability to obtain an Athletic Coaching License (https://webnew.ped.state.nm.us/bureaus/licensure/how-to-apply/athletic-coach-5-12/) from the New Mexico Public Education Department as well as completing the Fundamentals of Coaching online exam offered through the New Mexico Activities Association. (www.nmact.org)
QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program. 2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports) 3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions. REPORTS TO: The athletic director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principals. WORK ENVIRONMENT: On-site attendance is mandatory for this position. SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal. JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self-discipline, self-confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc. Work with students interested in sports, provide necessary practice support and advice for a team to be successful against opposing teams in a sports season. Teach and enforce rules and regulations. Involves work on evenings and weekends.

Physical/Cognitive Requirements: Must be able to fully perform the duties associated with coaching: lift 50 pounds, carry items to sites, maintain professional relations/communications with supervisor, parents, student-athletes, the media, boosters, officials, and co-workers.). Must possess and maintain a valid New Mexico Driver’s License. Environmental Conditions: Must be able to fully perform the duties associated with coaching: lift 50 pounds, carry items to sites, maintain professional relations/communications with supervisor, parents, student-athletes, the media, boosters, officials, and co-workers. Personal Accountability: 1. Demonstrates reliability as evidenced by attendance records and punctuality. 2. Properly notifies supervisor and/or designee of absences or tardiness. 3. Begins and completes work within the allotted time. 4. Consistently appears in attire appropriate to the work environment. 5. Demonstrates skill in the use of equipment including its capabilities, limitations and appropriate/ special application. 6. Protects the district’s resources through appropriate and careful use of supplies and equipment. 7. Utilizes appropriate body mechanics to aid in the prevention of muscle strain/injury.

Job.JobDescription:
The VHS-ASSISTANT TRACK COACH 25-26 17 role at Los Lunas Public Schools is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the VHS-ASSISTANT TRACK COACH 25-26 17 is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Los Lunas Public Schools are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The VHS-ASSISTANT TRACK COACH 25-26 17 listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the VHS-ASSISTANT TRACK COACH 25-26 17 encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The VHS-ASSISTANT TRACK COACH 25-26 17 follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Los Lunas Public Schools, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the VHS-ASSISTANT TRACK COACH 25-26 17 at Los Lunas Public Schools, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The BASEBALL BOYS JV - Assistant Coach (STIPEND) at Douglas High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the BASEBALL BOYS JV - Assistant Coach (STIPEND) plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Douglas High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The BASEBALL BOYS JV - Assistant Coach (STIPEND) expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the BASEBALL BOYS JV - Assistant Coach (STIPEND) supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the BASEBALL BOYS JV - Assistant Coach (STIPEND) may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Douglas High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) at Jerome High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Jerome High School, the Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Jerome High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Head Boys Lacrosse Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Grizell Middle School, the Head Boys Lacrosse Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Head Boys Lacrosse Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Grizell Middle School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Head Boys Lacrosse Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach at Grizell Middle School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Grizell Middle School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Grizell Middle School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Grizell Middle School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach role at Grizell Middle School.

The Head Softball Coach position at Grizell Middle School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Head Softball Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Grizell Middle School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Head Softball Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Head Softball Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Head Softball Coach role at Grizell Middle School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The Assistant Softball Coach position at Grizell Middle School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Assistant Softball Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Assistant Softball Coach at Grizell Middle School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Grizell Middle School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Assistant Softball Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Assistant Softball Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Assistant Softball Coach position at Grizell Middle School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.CompanyDescription: Westerville City School District coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Middle School Football Head Coach - 8th Grade
Job.JobDescription:
POSITION SUMMARY: Coach middle school grade level team(s), supervise a grade level middle school football program and coordinate the middle school program between grade levels and with high school program.
ESSENTIAL FUNCTION:
Organize and coach all practice sessions. Coach all scheduled games. Organize and coordinate practice schedules of all football teams at that grade level. Assure that students are supervised continuously and require students to behave appropriately. Supervise the distribution, collection and inventory of all equipment. Prepare written inventory of all equipment prior to start of season and at conclusion of season. Inspect all equipment and be responsible for seeing that equipment is maintained and safe for student use. Prepare equipment for reconditioning. Coordinate and supervise fitting of students for equipment. Prepare a written practice schedule and distribute weekly to students/parents, Middle School Athletic Director and Middle School Administrators. Collect, maintain, and distribute to appropriate personnel all emergency medical forms and medical information about students. Conduct parent meeting prior to start of season. Prepare budget for MMS football program that is submitted to MMS Athletic Director. Prepare written budget requests for MMS athletic director that will be forwarded to Quarterback Club. Comply with the academic eligibility requirements of the Ohio High School Athletic Association, the Marysville School District and the Marysville Middle School. Inform students and their parents weekly of any eligibility problems or if student is ineligible Organize and conduct award program. Observe all safety and health regulations of the school district. Maintain medical kits. Prepare and organize all necessary records and forms. Complete paperwork as directed by MMS athletic director and/or building administrators. Serve as a role model for student athletes in the promotion and practice of sportsmanship, ethical principles and responsible behavior. Communicate effectively and work cooperatively with students, staff, parents and community members. Prepare written announcements regarding practices, games, etc. for MMS announcements. Prepare written summaries and information concerning MMS football games, etc. for local newspaper. Inspect MMS game and practice facilities and report to MMS Athletic Director any concerns, etc. concerning facilities. Uphold the rules and guidelines of the OHSAA, Board of Education, Athletic Department and the MMS Student Handbook. Coordinate the MMS Football program with MHS Football program. Communicate with MHS Head Varsity Coach and MHS Football assistants about skills to be taught, etc. at this level. Maintain the locker room facilities. Organize and supervise the physical conditioning program prior to start of season. Provide written information to students and MMS Athletic Director about such programs prior to end of previous school year. Communicate any violations of policies or improper conduct of coaches to MMS Athletic Director in a prompt and timely manner. Supervise other MMS Football coaches and provide written input to MMS Athletic Director for the purpose of evaluating these coaches. Communicate regularly and frequently with the other MMS Head Football Coach in order to coordinate the total MMS Football program.
OTHER DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
Other duties may be assigned by the Middle School Athletic Director, Middle School Principal or High School Head Football Coach.
QUALIFICATIONS:
Pupil Activity Supervisor Validation. Ohio teaching certificate/license preferred. CPR certification with mandatory annual review.
REQUIRED KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS AND ABILITIES:
Ability to teach and evaluate the skills of the sport. Football experience and/or knowledge of football. Ability to effectively supervise high school athletes and work with them in a positive manner. Ability to work cooperatively with adults. Ability to meet the practice and contest time requirements specified by the Athletic Director or Principal.
EQUIPMENT OPERATED:
Blocking and tackling sleds. Audiovisual equipment.
WORKING CONDITIONS:
Potential exposure to blood or other bodily fluids. Regular exposure to hazardous athletic equipment. Close proximity to people running. Potential exposure to unruly people. Exposure to dust, pollen and inclement weather conditions. NOTE: The above lists may not be ranked in order of importance.
CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT:
Length of Employment: Contract runs concurrent with school year; Football season will run approximately August through November Salary: Supplemental pay, step one or appropriate experience step level Fringe Benefits: None
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION: Please submit a letter of interest and resume to the online application. Please do not send materials through U.S. mail or by e-mail, all documents should be uploaded to your application.
If your qualifications meet our needs we will contact you for further information and a possible interview.
The Marysville Exempted Village School District is an EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER and is in compliance with SECTION 504 OF THE REHABILITATION ACT OF 1973.

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: Coach all practice sessions and all scheduled games. Supervise students continuously while on duty and require students to behave appropriately. Distribute, collect and inventory the equipment. Assist with maintaining the locker room facilities. Assist with recordkeeping and the presentation of awards to the athletes. Communicate effectively and work cooperatively with students, staff, parents and community members. Observe all safety and health regulations of the school district. Follow the Athletic Director's rules and the applicable rules in the high school student handbook. QUALIFICATIONS: Pupil Activity Supervisor Validation. Ohio teaching certificate/license preferred. CPR certification with mandatory annual review. REQUIRED KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS AND ABILITIES: Ability to teach and evaluate the skills of the sport. Baseball experience and/or knowledge of baseball. Ability to effectively supervise high school athletes and work with them in a positive manner. Ability to work cooperatively with adults. Ability to meet the practice and contest time requirements specified by the Athletic Director or Principal. EQUIPMENT OPERATED: Mowers and field lining equipment. Pitching machines. Batting cages. WORKING CONDITIONS: Potential exposure to blood or other body fluids. Regular exposure to hazardous athletic equipment. Close proximity to people running. Potential exposure to unruly people. Exposure to dust, pollen and inclement weather conditions. NOTE: The above lists may not be ranked in order of importance. CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT: Length of Employment: Contract runs concurrent with school year; baseball season will run approximately February through June Salary: Supplemental pay, Step One or appropriate experience step level Fringe Benefits: None ADDITIONAL INFORMATION: Please submit a letter of interest and resume to the online application. Job.JobDescription:
Additional Information:
Opening for a High School Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach for the 2026-27 season.
Applicant must have or obtain a current Pupil Activity Permit and CPR.
If you have questions, please contact Chuck Jaco at 419-874-3181 X5194.
Qualifications:
1. Valid driver's license 2. State of Ohio Teaching License (preferred, not required). 3. Coaching and administrative abilities. 4. Required to maintain a valid CPR card, BCI and certification from the Ohio Department of Education through the Pupil Activity Validation Program. Proof of both certificates must be on file with the Athletic Director prior to coaching. 5. Ability to relate to, communicate with and inspire young athletes.

The MS Baseball Coach role at New Albany Middle School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the MS Baseball Coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At New Albany Middle School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The MS Baseball Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At New Albany Middle School, the MS Baseball Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the MS Baseball Coach at New Albany Middle School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

The Weight Room Supervisor - Spring (Internal Only) at OF HIGH SCHOOL is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Weight Room Supervisor - Spring (Internal Only) are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at OF HIGH SCHOOL use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Weight Room Supervisor - Spring (Internal Only) recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Weight Room Supervisor - Spring (Internal Only) collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Weight Room Supervisor - Spring (Internal Only) maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at OF HIGH SCHOOL. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.
Job.Location: OF HIGH SCHOOL - Olmsted Falls, Ohio

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (Internal Only) role at OF HIGH SCHOOL is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (Internal Only) is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at OF HIGH SCHOOL are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (Internal Only) listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (Internal Only) encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (Internal Only) follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At OF HIGH SCHOOL, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (Internal Only) at OF HIGH SCHOOL, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The Head Boys Tennis Coach (Internal Only) position at OF HIGH SCHOOL is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Head Boys Tennis Coach (Internal Only) works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Head Boys Tennis Coach (Internal Only) at OF HIGH SCHOOL sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At OF HIGH SCHOOL, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Head Boys Tennis Coach (Internal Only) encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Head Boys Tennis Coach (Internal Only) is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Head Boys Tennis Coach (Internal Only) position at OF HIGH SCHOOL is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The Head Softball Coach position at Rob Coxon is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Head Softball Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Rob Coxon, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Head Softball Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Head Softball Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Head Softball Coach role at Rob Coxon is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The Boys Junior Varsity Baseball Coach at Maple Heights High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Boys Junior Varsity Baseball Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Maple Heights High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Boys Junior Varsity Baseball Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Boys Junior Varsity Baseball Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Boys Junior Varsity Baseball Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Maple Heights High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The Head Girls Volleyball Coach (26-27) role at GRANVILLE HIGH SCHOOL emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Head Girls Volleyball Coach (26-27) coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At GRANVILLE HIGH SCHOOL, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Head Girls Volleyball Coach (26-27) reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent GRANVILLE HIGH SCHOOL at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Head Girls Volleyball Coach (26-27) may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Head Girls Volleyball Coach (26-27) monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Head Girls Volleyball Coach (26-27) must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at GRANVILLE HIGH SCHOOL.

Job.JobTitle: Head Cheerleading Coach - Immediate Opening or Fall 2026
Job.JobDescription: HEAD CHEERLEADING COACH – POSITION POSTING Indian Hill Exempted Village School District POSITION: Head Cheerleading Coach LOCATION: Indian Hill High School STARTING DATE: IMMEDIATE, SPRING 2026 or FALL 2027 CATEGORY: Supplemental REPORTS TO: Athletic Director STATUS: FLSA Exempt; Section 3319.02 – ORC TERMS: If interested, contact: Brian Phelps, Athletic Director GENERAL DESCRIPTION Indian Hill High School is home to one of Ohio’s most vibrant, high-performing school communities — a place where excellence is the expectation and spirit runs deep. As the Head Cheerleading Coach, you’ll lead a program that energizes our athletes, ignites our crowds, and helps shape the culture of pride across our campus. Our cheerleaders are enthusiastic, hardworking, and eager to grow, and they thrive under strong leadership that blends skill development, teamwork, and tradition. This role offers the opportunity to build a dynamic, student-centered cheer program that inspires school spirit at games, competitions, and community events. You’ll coach in a district known statewide for its commitment to student success, supportive families, and a collaborative athletic department that values innovation and heart. If you’re passionate about developing athletes, cultivating leadership, and creating unforgettable experiences for students and fans alike — Indian Hill is the place to make your mark. Indian Hill High School is a high-achieving Division II athletic program serving approximately 650 students in grades 9–12. The district emphasizes excellence, character, and student development. Candidates must possess all required Ohio Department of Education coaching credentials and successfully complete FBI/BCI background checks. PREFERRED SKILLS • Previous head coaching or assistant coaching experience in cheerleading preferred • Experience in choreography, stunting safety, and game-day leadership • Ability to develop strong culture, spirit, and team cohesion
Job.CompanyDescription: Indian Hill Exempted Village coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach at Jay Ohlinger is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Jay Ohlinger, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Jay Ohlinger operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Jay Ohlinger with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach role at Jay Ohlinger.
