The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Jay Ohlinger, the Assistant Track Coach (2 Positions: Throws and Sprints) is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Assistant Track Coach (2 Positions: Throws and Sprints) at Jay Ohlinger is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

The Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) role at Jay Schwanke is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Jay Schwanke are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Jay Schwanke, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) at Jay Schwanke, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

REPORTS TO: High School Principal and Athletic Director
EMPLOYMENT STATUS: Temporary, part-time
POSITION SUMMARY: Serve as JV Cheerleading Coach for high school sports activities.
ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS:
Conduct and/or supervise all activities needed for the selection of cheerleaders. Coach or supervise all practice sessions and scheduled events. Assure that students are supervised continuously and require students to behave appropriately. Distribute, collect and inventory the equipment. Complete and store all necessary records and forms. Conduct awards programs and present awards to the cheerleaders. Communicate effectively and work cooperatively with students, staff, parents and community members. Serve as a role model for student athletes in the promotion and practice of sportsmanship, ethical principles and responsible behavior. Comply with the academic eligibility requirements of the Ohio High School Athletic Association, the Marysville School District and the Marysville High School. Assure the squad's adherence to the cheerleading constitution, and follow the Athletic Department's rules and the applicable rules in the high school student handbook. Coordinate pep assemblies. Observe all safety and health regulations of the school district. Maintain the locker room facilities. Supervise and evaluate the cheerleading program.
OTHER DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
Other duties may be assigned by the High School Athletic Director or the High School Principal.
QUALIFICATIONS:
Pupil Activity Supervisor Validation. Ohio teaching certificate/license preferred. CPR certification with mandatory annual review.
REQUIRED KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS AND ABILITIES:
Ability to teach and evaluate the skills of cheerleading. Cheerleading experience and/or knowledge of cheerleading. Ability to effectively supervise high school cheerleaders and work with them in a positive manner. Ability to work cooperatively with adults. Ability to meet the practice and contest time requirements specified by the Athletic Director or Principal.
EQUIPMENT OPERATED:
Audiovisual equipment. School vans.
WORKING CONDITIONS:
Potential exposure to blood or other body fluids. Regular exposure to hazardous athletic equipment. Close proximity to people running. Potential exposure to unruly people. Exposure to dust, pollen and inclement weather conditions. NOTE: The above lists may not be ranked in order of importance.
CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT:
Length of Employment: Contract runs concurrent with school year; fall cheerleading season will run approximately August through November Salary: Supplemental pay; step one or appropriate experience step level Fringe Benefits: None
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION: Please submit a letter of interest and resume to the online application. Please do not send materials through U.S. mail or by e-mail, all documents should be uploaded to your application.
Job.SalaryRange: Supplemental pay; step one or appropriate experience step level

Job.JobDescription:
Jenks Public Schools Job Description
Qualifications:
1. High School Diploma/GED required.
2. One year of experience in coaching or participation at the high school or college level preferred.
3. Evidence of ability to work with student athletes in volleyball preferred.
4. Oklahoma CDL with P & S endorsements or ability to obtain one.

Position Goal: Assist with all aspects of student-athlete development and performance of the volleyball program.

4. Collaborate with the coordinator, assistant coordinator and the Booster Club.

Job.JobTitle: Boys Volleyball - Assistant Coach, McNary High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Boys Volleyball - Assistant Coach, McNary High School at McNary High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Boys Volleyball - Assistant Coach, McNary High School are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at McNary High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Boys Volleyball - Assistant Coach, McNary High School recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Boys Volleyball - Assistant Coach, McNary High School collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Boys Volleyball - Assistant Coach, McNary High School maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at McNary High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription: Posting Timeline This job is open until filled. Applications will be reviewed as received. Portland Public Schools reserves the right to make a hiring decision at any point during the posting period. Position Details DISTRICT MISSION: At PPS, our goal is that by the end of elementary, middle and high school every student by name is meeting or exceeding academic standards and is fully prepared to make productive life decisions. DISTRICT PROFILE: To obtain more information about our district, schools, learning environment and programs, please go to https://www.pps.net/Domain/265. Key points of the job description for a Varsity Head Coach: High ethical and professional standards. Direct a successful grade 9-12 program and oversee all facets of an entire community youth program. 3 years of High School coaching experience Be a role model for high school student-athletes. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports by encouraging student-athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program. Lead student-athletes in the support of other Portland Public Schools athletics and activities. The Head Coach will be responsible for the following: Manage all aspects of the high school program including training, practice schedules and routines. Hire and oversee a staff of assistant coaches Provide regular communication with parents/families Regularly track the academic progress of all student athletes in the program and facilitate necessary supports to ensure their academic eligibility. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports and encourage athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program for athletics. All new hired coaches will need to complete the following prior to employment: NFHS/ASEP Certification First Aid Card (CPR and AED trained) District Fingerprinting/Criminal check Completion of OSAA Concussion Test Completion of ODE Steroid Test Completion of OSAA Heat Test *Head Up Football *Cheer and Dance/Drill Spirit Safety Training Completion of Portland Public School District paperwork and trainings. Applicant will be asked to apply online at our website and include the following: A cover letter detailing your experience. A current resume. A minimum of three letters of recommendation/reference. All PPS job offers are contingent on the satisfactory completion of a background check, including fingerprinting and criminal records. Salary Range - $6100.00 to $10,000.00 * There is no compensation for summer and out of season workouts. Portland Public Schools (PPS) is seeking talented people from diverse backgrounds and experiences to lead change and inspire PPS students. At PPS, every employee, despite having different roles, is an educator. We hope to attract talented educators who model the core PPS Educator Essentials. With the District’s focus on eliminating systemic racism and its adverse impact on student learning, we seek to hire individuals who bring to our district a deep commitment to racial equity and social justice. The District is committed to equal opportunity and nondiscrimination in all its educational and employment activities. The District prohibits discrimination based on perceived or actual race; national or ethnic origin; color; sex; religion; age; sexual orientation; gender expression or identity; pregnancy; marital status; veteran’s status; familial status; economic status or source of income; mental or physical disability or perceived disability; or military service. 504 Coordinator: Marquita Guzman,mguzman@pps.net, 971-393-8633 ADA Coordinator: Jey Buno, jbuno@pps.net, 503-916-3360 Civil Rights Director: Dr. Bobby Cruz, bcruz@pps.net, 503-839-3660

Job.JobTitle: 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract - PMS - ASST. Coach - Boys Soccer
Job.JobDescription:
The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract - PMS - ASST. Coach - Boys Soccer role at Peirce Middle School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract - PMS - ASST. Coach - Boys Soccer coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Peirce Middle School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract - PMS - ASST. Coach - Boys Soccer reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Peirce Middle School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract - PMS - ASST. Coach - Boys Soccer may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract - PMS - ASST. Coach - Boys Soccer monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract - PMS - ASST. Coach - Boys Soccer must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Peirce Middle School.

TB must be dated within the last 90-days. * PA State Police Clearance (Act 34) * Child Abuse Clearance (Act 151) * FBI Fingerprint Clearance (Act 114) * School Personnel Health Form (Physical and TB test) * PDE 6004 Form (Act 24) * Sexual Misconduct/Abuse Disclosure Release Form(s) (Act 168) Procedure: Interested candidates must submit and application online. EOE Position Type: Coach / Extra Duty Job Categories: Athletics & Activities > Coaching Job Requirements * High School/Trade School degree preferred. * Citizenship, residency or work visa required

The Softball - Assistant Coach (2) at William Tennent High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Softball - Assistant Coach (2) is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At William Tennent High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Softball - Assistant Coach (2) helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Softball - Assistant Coach (2) works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at William Tennent High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent William Tennent High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Softball - Assistant Coach (2) reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Softball - Assistant Coach (2) role at William Tennent High School.

The Game Help/Volunteer Coach position at Lebanon is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Game Help/Volunteer Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Game Help/Volunteer Coach at Lebanon sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Lebanon, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Game Help/Volunteer Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Game Help/Volunteer Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Game Help/Volunteer Coach position at Lebanon is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The coach will also be responsible for fostering a positive and inclusive team culture, ensuring the safety and well-being of players, and always representing the school professionally. The Boys' & Girls' Outdoor Track Coach at Hope Highlands Middle School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Boys' & Girls' Outdoor Track Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Hope Highlands Middle School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Boys' & Girls' Outdoor Track Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Boys' & Girls' Outdoor Track Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Boys' & Girls' Outdoor Track Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Hope Highlands Middle School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The Head Softball Coach role at Hugh B. Bain Middle School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Head Softball Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Hugh B. Bain Middle School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Head Softball Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Head Softball Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Head Softball Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Hugh B. Bain Middle School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Head Softball Coach at Hugh B. Bain Middle School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Summary: Athletic positions require someone with proven decision-making skills, a track record of initiative and effort and a commitment to young people and education. Our jobs require a “people person” that indicates through actions a personality that is conducive to positive interactions with students, staff and parents.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Assistant Varsity Boys Soccer Coach - Timberland High
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Assistant Varsity Boys Soccer Coach - Timberland High position at Berkeley County is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Assistant Varsity Boys Soccer Coach - Timberland High is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Berkeley County, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Assistant Varsity Boys Soccer Coach - Timberland High encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Assistant Varsity Boys Soccer Coach - Timberland High also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Assistant Varsity Boys Soccer Coach - Timberland High role at Berkeley County is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

POSITION PURPOSE: Prepares each participating student athlete for competition in sports activities, and helps them to achieve a high level of skill, an appreciation for the values of discipline and sportsmanship, and an increased level of self-esteem.
ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: Prioritize athletics as a supplemental program to support the academic mission of the school. Carry out the aims and objectives of the sports program as outlined by the Athletic Director and school district administration. Instruct athletes in individual and team fundamentals, sportsmanship, cooperation, strategy and playing tactics, and physical conditioning necessary to realize individual and team success. Assist the Athletic Director in scheduling intramural and interscholastic contests. Assist in planning and scheduling a regular program of practice in season. Maintain required attendance forms, insurance records, and other related documents. Assist in oversight of safety conditions in the facility or area in which the assigned sport is conducted at all times student athletes are present. Assist in establishing and implementing performance criteria for academic eligibility in interscholastic competition of the identified sport. Enforce code of conduct standards and sportsmanship-like behavior at all times; establish and oversee penalties for breach of standards by student athletes. Recommend purchase of equipment, supplies, uniforms, etc. as appropriate.
ADDITIONAL DUTIES: Performs other related tasks as assigned by the Athletic Director, Principal, Superintendent or other district office administrator as designated by the Superintendent.
QUALIFICATIONS: Previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. Knowledge and/or background in the assigned sport. Teaching certificate and experience preferred. Must be able to pass criminal background check. Valid drivers license.
EXPERIENCE: Must have knowledge of South Carolina High School League rules and eligibility. Must be cooperative, service-oriented, and able to work effectively with frequent interruptions.
Job.Experience: Previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport.

Job.JobDescription:
POSITION PURPOSE: Prepares each participating student athlete for competition in sports activities, and helps them to achieve a high level of skill, an appreciation for the values of discipline and sportsmanship, and an increased level of self-esteem.
ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: • Prioritize athletics as a supplemental program to support the academic mission of the school. • Carry out the aims and objectives of the sports program as outlined by the Athletic Director and school district administration. • Instruct athletes in individual and team fundamentals, sportsmanship, cooperation, strategy and playing tactics, and physical conditioning necessary to realize individual and team success. • Assist the Athletic Director in scheduling intramural and interscholastic contests. • Assist in planning and scheduling a regular program of practice in season. • Maintain required attendance forms, insurance records, and other related documents. • Assist in oversight of safety conditions in the facility or area in which the assigned sport is conducted at all times student athletes are present. • Assist in establishing and implementing performance criteria for academic eligibility in interscholastic competition of the identified sport. • Enforce code of conduct standards and sportsmanlike behavior at all times; establish and oversee penalties for breach of standards by student athletes. • Recommend purchase of equipment, supplies, uniforms, etc. as appropriate.
ADDITIONAL DUTIES: Performs other related tasks as assigned by the Athletic Director, Principal, Superintendent or other district office administrator as designated by the Superintendent.
QUALIFICATIONS: • Previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. • Knowledge and/or background in the assigned sport. • Teaching certificate and experience preferred. • Must be able to pass criminal background check. • Valid drivers license.
EXPERIENCE: • Must have knowledge of South Carolina High School League rules and eligibility. • Must be cooperative, service-oriented, and able to work effectively with frequent interruptions.
Job.Experience: Previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport.

The Football Coordinator - High School role at Nation Ford High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Football Coordinator - High School is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Nation Ford High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Football Coordinator - High School listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Football Coordinator - High School encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Football Coordinator - High School follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Nation Ford High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Football Coordinator - High School at Nation Ford High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.
Job.Location: Nation Ford High School - Fort Mill, South Carolina

Job.JobDescription:
Reports To: School Athletic Director and/or School Administration
Job Summary: Rock Hill Schools is seeking a dedicated and knowledgeable Athletic Coach to lead, motivate, and develop athletes to reach their highest potential in both skill and character. The Athletic Coach will plan and implement practice sessions, guide athletes in training and competition, promote teamwork and sportsmanship, and ensure the health and safety of all participants.
Key Responsibilities: * Develop and execute effective training programs and practice plans. * Instruct athletes in the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport. * Evaluate athlete performance and provide constructive feedback. * Foster a positive team culture that emphasizes discipline, effort, integrity, and mutual respect. * Ensure adherence to all rules and regulations set by the school, league, or governing body. * Monitor the physical and mental condition of athletes, including injury prevention and first response. * Coordinate with assistant coaches, athletic trainers, and other staff. * Communicate regularly with athletes, parents, and administration. * Attend all practices, games, meetings, and required events. * Maintain equipment and inventory related to the specific sport. * Serve as a role model and mentor to student-athletes.
Qualifications: * Proven coaching experience in [specific sport, e.g., basketball, soccer, track, etc.]. * Knowledge of sport-specific techniques, rules, and strategies. * Excellent leadership, motivational, and organizational skills. * Strong interpersonal and communication abilities. * Satisfactory background report
Preferred: * Experience coaching at the [high school/collegiate/professional] level. * Relevant coaching certification (e.g., NFHS, USA Coaching, etc.)
Start Date: Determined by Human Resources
PRE-ONBOARDING REQUIREMENTS: As a condition of employment and prior to onboarding, the district will conduct a criminal history background check. The recommended candidate will be required to provide personal information necessary to complete the background check such as date of birth, gender, and race to remain in compliance with applicable laws and regulations.
DISCLAIMER: The District reserves the right to modify job postings and/or job descriptions at any time to meet organizational needs.
EEOC STATEMENT: Rock Hill Schools provides equal employment opportunities to all employees and applicants for employment and prohibits discrimination and harassment of any type without regard to race, color, religion, age, sex, national origin, disability status, genetics, protected veteran status, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, or any other characteristic protected by federal, state or local laws.
Job Requirements: * Citizenship, residency or work visa required

The Head Womens Varsity Swim Coach at Taryn Floyd is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Head Womens Varsity Swim Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Taryn Floyd, the Head Womens Varsity Swim Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Head Womens Varsity Swim Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Taryn Floyd well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Head Womens Varsity Swim Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

The Middle School Football Coach position at James Gildea is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Middle School Football Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Middle School Football Coach at James Gildea sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At James Gildea, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Middle School Football Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Middle School Football Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Middle School Football Coach position at James Gildea is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The Unified Basketball (Winter Season) position at Perth Amboy High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Unified Basketball (Winter Season) works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Unified Basketball (Winter Season) at Perth Amboy High School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Perth Amboy High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Unified Basketball (Winter Season) encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Unified Basketball (Winter Season) is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Unified Basketball (Winter Season) position at Perth Amboy High School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The Unified Track (Spring Season) position at Perth Amboy High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Unified Track (Spring Season) is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Perth Amboy High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Unified Track (Spring Season) encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Unified Track (Spring Season) also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Unified Track (Spring Season) role at Perth Amboy High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

ATHLETIC AND ACTIVITY DIRECTOR Reports To: Deputy Superintendent Salary: Administrative Calendar: 240 Days
JOB SUMMARY The Athletic and Activity Director is responsible for the administration, supervision, and coordination of all district-sanctioned athletic and student activity programs for grades 7–12. The position provides leadership in developing, implementing, and sustaining a comprehensive, educationally sound athletics and activities program that aligns with district goals, Board policy, and New Mexico Activities Association (NMAA) requirements. QUALIFICATIONS Valid New Mexico Administrative License. Master’s Degree in education or related field preferred. Minimum of five years of successful teaching and/or administrative experience. Minimum of five years of successful coaching or athletic administration experience preferred. Such alternatives to the above qualifications as the Superintendent may find appropriate and acceptable. ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES Program Leadership and Development Compliance and Eligibility Scheduling, Events, and Travel Budgeting and Financial Oversight Facilities and Event Operations Records, Recognition, and Communication Professional Responsibilities The physical demands described are representative of those required to perform the essential functions of this position. Reasonable accommodations may be made. While performing the duties of this job, the employee is regularly required to sit, stand, walk, use hands to finger, handle, or feel, and talk or hear. Ability to lift and/or move up to 25 pounds Visual abilities including close, distance, color, peripheral, and depth perception WORKING CONDITIONS Mental Demands/Physical Demands/Environmental Factors: Maintain emotional control under stress, work with frequent interruptions. Some districtwide and statewide travel. Occasional, prolonged and irregular working hours. TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT Salary and work year shall be in accordance with the current administrative schedule. This is a 240-day contract. EVALUATION Performance will be evaluated in accordance with Board of Education policy on administrator evaluations. Note: This is not an exhaustive or all-inclusive list of responsibilities, skills, duties, requirements, efforts, functions or working conditions associated with the job. This job description is not a contract of employment or a promise or guarantee of any specific terms or conditions of employment. The school district may add to, modify or delete any aspect of this job (or the position itself) at any time as it deems advisable. Revised February 2026 THE DEMING PUBLIC SCHOOL DISTRICT IS AN EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER AND DOES NOT DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF RACE, NATIONAL ORIGIN, RELIGION, AGE, SEX, MARITAL STATUS, OR HANDICAP IN COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL AND STATE LAWS Position Type: Full-Time Job Requirements Citizenship, residency or work visa required

Job.JobTitle: VHS-ASSISTANT TRACK COACH 25-26 17 (Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School)
Job.JobDescription:
The VHS-ASSISTANT TRACK COACH 25-26 17 (Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School) position at Los Lunas Public Schools provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the VHS-ASSISTANT TRACK COACH 25-26 17 (Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School) prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Los Lunas Public Schools, the VHS-ASSISTANT TRACK COACH 25-26 17 (Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School) works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The VHS-ASSISTANT TRACK COACH 25-26 17 (Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School) encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the VHS-ASSISTANT TRACK COACH 25-26 17 (Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School) at Los Lunas Public Schools is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.
Job.SalaryRange: As established by the Los Lunas Schools current Increment Salary Schedule. As per NMAA Season.
Job.CompanyDescription: Los Lunas Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
Position: Assistant Coach Supervisor: Head Coach Work Site: Assigned Building/ Site
Summary: The Assistant Coach must demonstrate leadership in player and staff development, integrity, sportsmanship and character development. Qualified candidates should possess strong communication and organizational skills. They must demonstrate exceptional skills and strategies of their sport as it pertains to the policies of New Mexico Activities Association (NMAA).
Essential Duties and Responsibilities: Assist in implementing a written team rules which includes a philosophy statement and discusses acceptable player behavior, practice procedures, substance abuse policies and other guidelines that relate to program management. Conduct a pre-season meeting with parents and players to share these policies and procedures. Have a thorough knowledge of all District and the NMAA Policies and be responsible for their implementation. Continue professional growth by attending classes, clinics, workshops, and affiliations with professional organizations. Conduct oneself as a positive role model. Assist the head coach in implementing all team rules. Turn in team rosters as directed to the head coach. Report all rule violations or suspected violations to the head coach. Consult with the Head Coach, or his/her designee, in matters of purchasing equipment, scheduling, and coaching assignments. Work to develop a positive athlete-teacher relationship. Coaches must ensure that all athletes participating in their sport are academically eligible. This includes checking grades before the start of the season and during the season as well. Every student athlete must remain eligible according to NMAA policies. Assist in implementing a sport specific safety plan. This includes a hazards free practice environment, if something needs to be fixed, place a district work order to fix that problem immediately and report it to your head coach or Regional Activities Coordinator. Be responsible for the collection of equipment and have athletic fines resolved by the end of the season. Prepare travel rosters and itineraries prior to the 24 hours of departure. Remain at practice or contest until all athletes have left the athletic area. Inspect the locker room with the visiting coach before and after the contest. A Staff member must ride the team bus to and from practices or contests. Require appropriate behavior on road trips by supervising students in motels and restaurants. Promote and encourage fair play, good sportsmanship, and ethical standards of conduct both on and off the field. Forewarn all participants that involvement in physical confrontation could result in removal from the game and /or suspension from subsequent games. Maintain a yearly inventory of all new and used equipment. Comply with all Board of Education policies, administrative regulations, Public Education Department guidelines and local/state/federal laws and the NMAA. Coaches are required to upload athlete rosters into the NMAA approved database. Perform additional job responsibilities as assigned by the supervisor. By his/her presence at all practices, games and while traveling, provides assistance, guidance and safeguards for each participant. Initiates programs and policies concerning injuries, medical attention and emergencies. Completes reports of all disabling athletic injuries on proper forms and submits to the athletic office within 24 hours. Directs student managers, assistants and statisticians. Determines discipline, delineates procedures concerning due process when the enforcement of discipline is necessary and contacts parents when a student is dropped or becomes ineligible. Assists athletes in their college or advanced educational selection
Minimum Qualifications: Valid NM Athletic Coaching License Valid New Mexico Teaching License preferred All Athletic Coaches in K-8 settings MUST be at least 18 years of age, and ALL Athletic Coaches in 9-12 settings MUST be at least 21 years of age.
Knowledge, Skills and Abilities: Knowledge of Dine language, culture, and history preferred Good communication skills and customer service skills Understand and follow the proper administrative line of command and refer all requests or grievances through proper channels Has the ability to assist in organization and supervision of the total sports program The assistant coach must have knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and willingness to continue to learn and examine new ideas pertinent to the assigned sport
Physical/Job Requirements: Standing, sitting, walking, lifting, carrying up to 50 pounds, climbing, bending, reaching, kneeling, driving a vehicle, traveling long distances, writing, typing, word processing, reading, researching information, and effective communication skills.
Safety and Health: Knowledge of universal hygiene precautions Refer athletes with possible infections to a healthcare provider such as team physician, athletic trainer, school nurse or primary care doctor. Instruct athletes with a potential or confirmed infection or open wound to avoid using whirlpools or therapy pools not cleaned between athletes and other common-use water facilities like swimming pools until infections and wounds are healed. Review and implement cleaning and disinfecting guidelines-recommended by CDC: Environmental Cleaning & Disinfecting for Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureas {aka MRSA}. Educate athletes about ways to prevent spreading infections
Equipment/Material Handled: Multimedia equipment, including current technology Equipment/materials relevant to the job responsibilities Valid driver license and insurable by district if necessary
Work Environment: Must be able to work within various degrees of noise, temperature and air quality Work interruptions Flexibility Must be self-motivated and able to complete job assignment without direct supervision Must complete applications and assignments within the timeframes allowed Extended work hours, on occasion
Term of Employment: This is an extra-duty, supplemental assignment only. Acceptance of this position does not create a contract for employment nor any guarantee of continued employment of any duration. This supplemental position is At-Will and is terminable at the will of either party, with or without just cause, and without any requirement for a statement of any cause. Termination of this supplemental assignment does not create any appeal or grievance rights. This supplemental assignment has no bearing upon, nor is it affected by, any other supplemental assignment(s) or contracted position(s) held.

The Volunteer Coaches - Softball at Brian Brunswick is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Volunteer Coaches - Softball is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Brian Brunswick, the Volunteer Coaches - Softball helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Volunteer Coaches - Softball may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Brian Brunswick well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Volunteer Coaches - Softball follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription:
The 50% Freshman Girls Basketball Coach at Normandy High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the 50% Freshman Girls Basketball Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Normandy High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The 50% Freshman Girls Basketball Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the 50% Freshman Girls Basketball Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The 50% Freshman Girls Basketball Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Normandy High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.
Job.CompanyDescription: Parma City School District coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The 7th Grade Head Boys Track Coach at Shiloh Middle School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the 7th Grade Head Boys Track Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Shiloh Middle School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The 7th Grade Head Boys Track Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The 7th Grade Head Boys Track Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Shiloh Middle School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Shiloh Middle School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the 7th Grade Head Boys Track Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the 7th Grade Head Boys Track Coach role at Shiloh Middle School.

Job.JobTitle: Coaching - HS Varsity Asst. Track Coach - Coed
Job.JobDescription: Job Responsibilities: Serve as the Varsity Asst. Coach for the entire Track Program. Is knowledgeable about the sport and rules. Assist with developing, monitoring, supervising, and training student-athletes to participate in competitive Track. Assist with developing and executing an effective training program. Motivate and mentor student-athletes on and off the Track. Instruct and guide student-athletes in fundamental skills, strategies, and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. Instruct and guide student-athletes to lead them to the formulation and enhancement of moral values, pride of accomplishment, acceptable social behavior, self-discipline, and self-confidence. Foster teamwork, sportsmanship, and skills development. Ensure the safety and well-being of student-athletes. Cooperate, in a timely manner, with School Athletic Director and the District Athletic Department in regard to requests for information that might be pertinent and/or periodically required. Meet all the requirements set forth by the District Board of Education, The Ohio High School Athletic Association (OHSAA), and The Ohio Department of Education (ODE) relative to the mandated Coaches Tool Chest (CTC) Training/ Certification and the ODE Pupil Activity Permit. Check the status of academic eligibility for all prospective student-athletes. Follow the District Athletic Department Policies as outlined in the Coaches Handbook and meet all criteria as outlined in the job description. Model the behavior expected of our student-athletes including timeliness to practices and games, being positive and enthusiastic, being respectful, and practicing constructive criticism while upholding the disciplines of the program. Maintain a suitable sideline conduct, including the use of appropriate language, at all times. Accept and profit from constructive criticism and suggestions for improving coaching performance. Recognize the need to be aware of and implement all applicable administrative polices set forth by the District Board of Education, Superintendents of Schools, School Principals, Conference Leagues, ODE, and OHSAA. Schedule and complete a full season of contests including State Tournament Games. Provide all applicable in-season training rules as well as any that may apply to out-of-season conduct to student-athletes prior to the start of the season. Follow appropriate due process procedures when violations occur. Participate in Clinics and other available programs to improve coaching performance. Participate in School events (i.e., Awards Night, Pep Assemblies, Athletic Boosters Meetings, etc. Ensure that team is well-prepared for opponents. Maintain accurate inventory of equipment and supplies. SKILLS/QUALIFICATIONS: Fundraising experience Must be passionate and dedicated to inspire student-athletes. Have the ability to motivate and inspire student-athletes. Serve as a positive role model. Demonstrated knowledge and skills associated with the sport. TRAINING/CERTIFICATIONS: Ohio Secondary Teaching Certificate preferred. Evidence of successful past coaching experience at the High School and/or College level is preferred. Provide satisfactory result of County Police Records Check, State BCII Check, and a FBI Fingerprint Background Check. Possess an Ohio Department of Education (ODE) Pupil Activity Permit (PAP). Provide proof of completion of Coaches Tool Chest (CTC) Training/Certification. CONTRACT PROVISIONS: TYPE OF CONTRACT: Supplemental Annual Limited SALARY: Per Schedule E Contract of current C.F.T. Labor Agreement REPORTS TO: School Principal APPLICATION PROCEDURE: Apply online via CPS Unified Talent SELECTION PROCEDURE: Interview Job Requirements At least 3 year(s) of relevant experience preferred. Citizenship, residency or work visa required
Job.SalaryRange: Per Schedule E Contract of current C.F.T. Labor Agreement
