Job.JobTitle: Cross Country - Varsity Assistant Coach - Girls (2025-2026)
Job.JobDescription:
The Cross Country - Varsity Assistant Coach - Girls position at Irmo High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Cross Country - Varsity Assistant Coach - Girls prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Irmo High School, the Cross Country - Varsity Assistant Coach - Girls works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Cross Country - Varsity Assistant Coach - Girls encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Cross Country - Varsity Assistant Coach - Girls at Irmo High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The Wrestling - Varsity Assistant Coach - 2025 at Chapin High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Wrestling - Varsity Assistant Coach - 2025 is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Chapin High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Wrestling - Varsity Assistant Coach - 2025 helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Wrestling - Varsity Assistant Coach - 2025 works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Chapin High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Chapin High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Wrestling - Varsity Assistant Coach - 2025 reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Wrestling - Varsity Assistant Coach - 2025 role at Chapin High School.

Reports To: School Athletic Director and/or School Administration
Job Summary: Rock Hill Schools is seeking a dedicated and knowledgeable Athletic Coach to lead, motivate, and develop athletes to reach their highest potential in both skill and character. The Athletic Coach will plan and implement practice sessions, guide athletes in training and competition, promote teamwork and sportsmanship, and ensure the health and safety of all participants.
Key Responsibilities: Develop and execute effective training programs and practice plans. Instruct athletes in the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport. Evaluate athlete performance and provide constructive feedback. Foster a positive team culture that emphasizes discipline, effort, integrity, and mutual respect. Ensure adherence to all rules and regulations set by the school, league, or governing body. Monitor the physical and mental condition of athletes, including injury prevention and first response. Coordinate with assistant coaches, athletic trainers, and other staff. Communicate regularly with athletes, parents, and administration. Attend all practices, games, meetings, and required events. Maintain equipment and inventory related to the specific sport. Serve as a role model and mentor to student-athletes.

Job.JobDescription:
Our Human Resources Team at the Greenville County School District is dedicated to advancing student achievement by recruiting and employing the highest qualified staff for our schools and to serve those with whom we work.
Summary: Athletic positions require someone with proven decision-making skills, a track record of initiative and effort and a commitment to young people and education. Our jobs require a “people person” that indicates through actions a personality that is conducive to positive interactions with students, staff and parents.

The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Head Track role at Thoreau High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Head Track is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Thoreau High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Head Track sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Thoreau High School, the 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Head Track is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Head Track at Thoreau High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Title: Athletic Coach � Assistant Golf Work Location: Gallup High School Contract Length: Spring Sport Minimum Salary: $5,000.00 Maximum Salary: $5,000.00
*Internal applicants MUST attach a signed Permission to Coach Form to application*
ATHLETIC COACHING LICENSE, 7-12
High School Diploma or Equivalency AND Must hold or have the ability to obtain an Athletic Coaching License (https://webnew.ped.state.nm.us/bureaus/licensure/how-to-apply/athletic-coach-7-12/) from the New Mexico Public Education Department as well as completing the Fundamentals of Coaching online exam offered through the New Mexico Activities Association. (www.nmact.org)
QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program. 2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports) 3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions.
REPORTS TO: The athletic director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principals.
SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal.
JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self-discipline, self-confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc.
Work with students interested in sports, provide necessary practice support and advice for a team to be successful against opposing teams in a sports season. Teach and enforce rules and regulations. Involves work on evenings and weekends.

Job.JobDescription:
The LLHS Assistant Softball Coach 25-26 role at Los Lunas Public Schools emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the LLHS Assistant Softball Coach 25-26 coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Los Lunas Public Schools, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The LLHS Assistant Softball Coach 25-26 reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Los Lunas Public Schools at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The LLHS Assistant Softball Coach 25-26 may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The LLHS Assistant Softball Coach 25-26 monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The LLHS Assistant Softball Coach 25-26 must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Los Lunas Public Schools.
Job.CompanyDescription: Los Lunas Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Head Boys Soccer Coach at Carlsbad High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Head Boys Soccer Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Carlsbad High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Head Boys Soccer Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Head Boys Soccer Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Head Boys Soccer Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Carlsbad High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The Assistant Girls Track Coach at Middle School South is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Assistant Girls Track Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Middle School South, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Assistant Girls Track Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Assistant Girls Track Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Assistant Girls Track Coach at Middle School South allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach role at MSE/MSS/MSW (combined) emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At MSE/MSS/MSW (combined), the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent MSE/MSS/MSW (combined) at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at MSE/MSS/MSW (combined).

The Head 7th Grade Girls Basketball Coach at Middle School South is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Head 7th Grade Girls Basketball Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Middle School South, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Head 7th Grade Girls Basketball Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Head 7th Grade Girls Basketball Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Middle School South operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Middle School South with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Head 7th Grade Girls Basketball Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Head 7th Grade Girls Basketball Coach role at Middle School South.

The Head Girls Tennis Coach role at MSE/MSS/MSW (combined) is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Head Girls Tennis Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at MSE/MSS/MSW (combined) are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Head Girls Tennis Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Head Girls Tennis Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Head Girls Tennis Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At MSE/MSS/MSW (combined), the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Head Girls Tennis Coach at MSE/MSS/MSW (combined), a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The Tennis, Junior Varsity Coach - Boys at Brunswick High School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Tennis, Junior Varsity Coach - Boys manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Brunswick High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Tennis, Junior Varsity Coach - Boys demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Tennis, Junior Varsity Coach - Boys follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Tennis, Junior Varsity Coach - Boys at Brunswick High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

The Vacancy - Soccer - JV Head (Boys) at Princeton High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Vacancy - Soccer - JV Head (Boys) is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Princeton High School, the Vacancy - Soccer - JV Head (Boys) helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Vacancy - Soccer - JV Head (Boys) may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Princeton High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Vacancy - Soccer - JV Head (Boys) follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Statement of Purpose and Values Alignment New Albany-Plain Local Schools (NAPLS) is committed to empowering all learners to reach their full potential by cultivating character, curiosity, and confidence. The High School Head Coach plays a critical leadership role in advancing the district’s purpose and values by providing an education-based athletic experience that develops the whole student—academically, athletically, socially, and ethically. Head Coaches are expected to model and promote the district’s core values, including respect, responsibility, integrity, belonging, and excellence, while ensuring athletics remains an extension of the educational mission of New Albany-Plain Local Schools.
Position Overview The High School Head Coach is the chief leader of the assigned interscholastic athletic program and is responsible for its vision, culture, administration, and performance. This position extends well beyond on-field coaching and requires strategic leadership, program development, staff supervision, and intentional student-athlete growth. The Head Coach is responsible for ensuring a safe, inclusive, and academically aligned program that complies with all district policies, New Albany-Plain Local Schools Athletic Department expectations, and all applicable Ohio High School Athletic Association (OHSAA) bylaws, regulations, and sport-specific rules. The High School Head Coach is expected to: Serve as the program leader and primary ambassador for the sport within the school and community. Establish and sustain a clear program philosophy aligned with district values and athletic department standards. Set and enforce high expectations for behavior, effort, accountability, sportsmanship, and citizenship. Foster a positive, inclusive, and respectful team culture where all students feel valued and supported. Model professionalism, ethical conduct, and sound judgment at all times.
Key Responsibilities Program Leadership & Culture Lead all aspects of the athletic program, including philosophy, culture, standards, and long-term vision. Build a developmentally focused program for grades 7-12 that emphasizes character, leadership, teamwork, and resilience. Align program practices and expectations with education-based athletics and student well-being. Student-Athlete Development Teach sport-specific skills, strategies, and conditioning appropriate to the level of play. Prioritize student-athlete safety, wellness, and injury prevention in collaboration with athletic training staff. Support and monitor academic progress, reinforcing the importance of classroom success. Promote personal growth, decision-making skills, and responsible behavior. Clearly define, articulate, implement, and create a culture of accountability for a sportsmanship program aligned with the athletic department and district expectations. Establish, clearly articulate and enforce competencies for the selection of team captains.
Staff Leadership & Supervision Recruit, recommend, mentor, supervise, and evaluate assistant coaches and approved volunteers. Clearly define staff roles and expectations and support professional growth. Ensure all coaching staff meet OHSAA, district, and state certification and training requirements.
Communication & Collaboration Maintain consistent, proactive, and professional communication with student-athletes, families, staff, and administrators. Clearly communicate program expectations, schedules, and updates through approved district platforms. Follow district communication protocols and collaborate with school and athletic department leadership.
Operations & Compliance Ensure compliance with all applicable OHSAA bylaws, sport regulations, eligibility requirements, and participation limits. Actively seek guidance or direction from the athletic director or principal to enforce the codes of conduct. Enforce OHSAA regulations related to out-of-season coaching, contact periods, open gyms, and conditioning. Complete all required eligibility, consent, physical, and participation documentation. Attend required athletic department, league, conference, and OHSAA meetings. Assist with scheduling, tournament planning, transportation coordination, and event supervision. Manage program equipment, uniforms, inventory, and facilities responsibly. Ensure compliance with fiduciary policies and guidelines, including fundraising with/for team, department, school, booster or other like organizations. Implement an awards program as directed or approved by the athletic director.
Program Development & Community Engagement Coordinate and lead off-season and summer development opportunities within OHSAA guidelines. Collaborate with strength and conditioning staff to support student development. Develop, implement and assist with post secondary recruitment efforts for student athletes. Build alignment with middle school and youth programs to support long-term program sustainability. Represent the program positively within the school and community.
Required Qualifications Prior coaching experience in the assigned sport at the high school, club, or collegiate level. Valid Ohio Department of Education Pupil Activity Permit or evidence of obtainability. Ability to meet all OHSAA coaching certification requirements, including but not limited to: Fundamentals of Coaching Concussion Education CPR/AED and First Aid certification Lindsay's Law and Sudden Cardiac Arrest training Demonstrated leadership, organization, and program management skills. Commitment to education-based athletics and student development.
Knowledge, Skills, and Abilities Ability to build and sustain a positive, inclusive, and student-centered program culture. Knowledge of district policies, athletic department procedures, and OHSAA bylaws and regulations. Expertise in sport-specific coaching techniques, training methods, and athlete development. Skill in mentoring, supervising, and evaluating coaching staff. Strong written and verbal communication skills. Effective organizational and time-management skills.

Reports to: Athletic Director and Head Coach
General Description: The position of assistant coach will be filled based upon input from the head coach, Athletic Director, and Building Principal and recommendation of the Superintendent to the board of education. The assistant coach must meet all provisions of the Lake Board of Education and the OHSAA.
Responsible to Athletic Director and head coach. Attend all meetings scheduled by the head coach. Assist in the administration of the athletic program. Demonstrate loyalty to the head coach and to the program. Maintain good public relations with those groups and individuals involved with the program. Support the Lake Athletic Booster Club. Conduct oneself in a professional manner at all times. Teach the values of good sportsmanship. Be available for Athletic Department meetings as necessary. Works through proper channels and protocol in referring parents or the public to appropriate administrative responses. Assume responsibilities of head coach in matters of supervision in absence of head coach.
Pre-Season responsibilities: be in attendance from the first day of practice. assist with the supervision of practices and games. assist with the issuance of equipment. assist in pre-season conditioning as assigned by the head coach.
In-Season responsibilities: carry out the duties assigned by the head coach. assist the trainer with his/her duties. scout other schools' teams as necessary. observe and communicate with feeder coaches in the program.
Off-season responsibilities: assist in the collection, storage, and inventory of equipment. assist with banquet activities. attend clinics when possible. assist with the off-season conditioning program.
Qualifications: Must possess a valid Pupil Activity Permit (and all necessary certificates).
Acts that are deemed as lude, sexual, or inappropriate will be viewed as unacceptable and may be considered as grounds for administrative action, dismissal, or termination of contract.
This job description is subject to change and in no manner states or implies that these are the only duties and responsibilities to be performed by the incumbent. The incumbent will be required to follow the instructions and perform the duties required by the incumbent's supervisor, appointing authority.

The CHS Spring Sports Supplementals 2026 position at Chillicothe High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the CHS Spring Sports Supplementals 2026 works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The CHS Spring Sports Supplementals 2026 at Chillicothe High School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Chillicothe High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The CHS Spring Sports Supplementals 2026 encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The CHS Spring Sports Supplementals 2026 is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the CHS Spring Sports Supplementals 2026 position at Chillicothe High School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobTitle: CMS Spring Sports Supplementals 2026 (Boys & Girls Track Coaches)
Job.JobDescription:
The CMS Spring Sports Supplementals 2026 (Boys & Girls Track Coaches) position at Chillicothe Middle School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The CMS Spring Sports Supplementals 2026 (Boys & Girls Track Coaches) is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Chillicothe Middle School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The CMS Spring Sports Supplementals 2026 (Boys & Girls Track Coaches) encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The CMS Spring Sports Supplementals 2026 (Boys & Girls Track Coaches) also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the CMS Spring Sports Supplementals 2026 (Boys & Girls Track Coaches) role at Chillicothe Middle School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

GRANVILLE EXEMPTED VILLAGE SCHOOL DISTRICT JOB DESCRIPTION Title: ASSISTANT COACH Reports to: Head Coach Job Objective: Uses technical expertise to coach the assigned athletic activity. Minimum Qualifications: Complies with drug-free workplace rules and board policies. Relevant coaching experience. Knowledgeable about interscholastic athletic program regulations. Completion of state activity supervisory permit requirements (e.g., first aid/CPR, etc.). Meets all mandated health requirements. A record free of criminal violations that would prohibit public school employment. NOTE: Supplemental contracts are offered to qualified certificated staff with appropriate training, knowledge, and experience. Unfilled positions may be offered to other suitable applicants meeting department of education permit requirements. Essential Functions: The following are typical work responsibilities. A reasonable accommodation may be made to enable a qualified individual with a disability to perform essential functions. Works with student athletes to improve personal and teamwork skills. Provides guidance and encouragement to help students benefit from participation in program activities. Upholds board policies and follows administrative guidelines/procedures. Promotes a professional image of the school district. Encourages community partnerships that enhance district programs. Promotes effective communications and assistance. Uses problem-solving techniques to tactfully address questions/concerns. Refers policy interpretation inquiries to administrative staff. Reviews procedures and schedules before the start of the season. Consults with the head coach to evaluate program needs. Promotes the proper use, care, and security of school property. Monitors innovations, evaluates activities, and recommends program improvements. Helps coordinate the development of off-season activities (e.g., summer training, clinics, etc.). Helps parents and students understand program objectives. Explains student responsibilities (e.g., scholastic eligibility permission forms, medical exams, activity schedules, letters, awards, participation certificates, insurance coverage, waiver forms, etc.). Encourages student involvement in program activities. Helps verify medical/scholastic eligibility. Promotes academic success as an important priority for all students. Helps organize team tryouts. Helps maintain the integrity of the selection process. Carries out the assigned practice schedule. Gives the head coach a copy of all student communications. Helps ensure that all athletes receive appropriate instruction, support, and opportunities to participate. Helps assign and track equipment issued to staff and students. Helps supervise the preparation of athletic fields and practice/training areas as directed. Teaches precautions and procedures to help students prevent injuries. Ensures that equipment is appropriate for participants' physical development and skill level. Helps ensure that all required medical authorizations forms are on file and readily available. Documents all injuries that require treatment. Helps evaluate individual/team performance. Helps develop/refine game strategies. Helps recruit, train, and supervise student managers, trainers, and scouts. Helps the activities director secure personnel for home games when requested. Upholds the student conduct code. Implements effective pupil management procedures. Models behavior that demonstrates respect for rules, officials, and opponents. Ensures that participant communications do not demean or ridicule mistakes and/or performance. Helps arrange transportation and accompanies the team to sanctioned athletic activities. Obtains permission to be away when duties conflict with other assigned duties. Provides guidance, communicates expectations, and shows an active interest in student progress. Participates in athletic recognition programs. Helps verify that participants have fulfilled all requirements for letters, awards, and/or participation certificates. Takes precautions to ensure safety. Monitors situations that may indicate a problem. Provides appropriate student supervision. Works with supervisors to manage or eliminate risk factors. Helps supervise approved fund raising projects. Works with the head coach to ensure that all financial activities are processed through the proper student activity account. Assists with collection, verification, and recording of program information as directed. Helps maintain accurate records. Submits reports on time. Participates in staff meetings, conferences, and other required school activities. Respects personal privacy. Maintains the confidentiality of privileged information. Reports suspected child abuse and/or neglect to civil authorities as required by law. Encourages parent organizations and supports school-sponsored activities. Pursues growth opportunities that enhance professional performance and advance district goals. Strives to develop rapport and serves as a positive role model for others. Maintains a professional appearance. Wears work attire appropriate for the position. The Granville Exempted Village School District Board of Education is an equal opportunity employer. This job description identifies general responsibilities and is not intended to be a complete list of all duties performed. This document is subject to change in response to student demographics, staffing factors, funding variables, modified operating procedures, and other unforeseen events.

The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Worthington Kilbourne High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Soccer - Girls - Head Coach at Worthington Kilbourne High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position ***2026-2027
Job.JobDescription:
The Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 at Lebanon Junior High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Lebanon Junior High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Lebanon Junior High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Lebanon Junior High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 role at Lebanon Junior High School.

Job.JobTitle: Lebanon City Schools: LHS Cross Country Coach Assistant ***2026-2027
Job.JobDescription:
The Lebanon City Schools: LHS Cross Country Coach Assistant *2026 position at Lebanon High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Lebanon City Schools: LHS Cross Country Coach Assistant *2026 prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Lebanon High School, the Lebanon City Schools: LHS Cross Country Coach Assistant *2026 works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Lebanon City Schools: LHS Cross Country Coach Assistant *2026 encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Lebanon City Schools: LHS Cross Country Coach Assistant *2026 at Lebanon High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The Head Softball Coach at Trey Jones is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Head Softball Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Trey Jones, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Head Softball Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Head Softball Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Head Softball Coach at Trey Jones allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

The 7th Grade Head Boys Track at Shiloh Middle School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the 7th Grade Head Boys Track plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Shiloh Middle School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The 7th Grade Head Boys Track expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the 7th Grade Head Boys Track supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the 7th Grade Head Boys Track may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Shiloh Middle School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

General Description: The position of assistant coach will be filled based upon input from the head coach, Athletic Director, and Building Principal and recommendation of the Superintendent to the board of education. The assistant coach must meet all provisions of the Lake Board of Education and the OHSAA.
Responsible to Athletic Director and head coach. Attend all meetings scheduled by the head coach. Assist in the administration of the athletic program. Demonstrate loyalty to the head coach and to the program. Maintain good public relations with those groups and individuals involved with the program. Support the Lake Athletic Booster Club. Conduct oneself in a professional manner at all times. Teach the values of good sportsmanship. Be available for Athletic Department meetings as necessary. Works through proper channels and protocol in referring parents or the public to appropriate administrative responses. Assume responsibilities of head coach in matters of supervision in absence of head coach.
Pre-Season responsibilities: be in attendance from the first day of practice. assist with the supervision of practices and games. assist with the issuance of equipment. assist in pre-season conditioning as assigned by the head coach.
In-Season responsibilities: carry out the duties assigned by the head coach. assist the trainer with his/her duties. scout other schools' teams as necessary. observe and communicate with feeder coaches in the program.
Off-season responsibilities: assist in the collection, storage, and inventory of equipment. assist with banquet activities. attend clinics when possible. assist with the off-season conditioning program.

The DANCE SPONSOR role at MacArthur Middle School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the DANCE SPONSOR is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at MacArthur Middle School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The DANCE SPONSOR listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the DANCE SPONSOR encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The DANCE SPONSOR follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At MacArthur Middle School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the DANCE SPONSOR at MacArthur Middle School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The DANCE SPONSOR at Central Middle School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the DANCE SPONSOR are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Central Middle School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The DANCE SPONSOR recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the DANCE SPONSOR collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The DANCE SPONSOR maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Central Middle School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics
Job.JobDescription:
Posting Timeline This job is open until filled. Applications will be reviewed as received. Portland Public Schools reserves the right to make a hiring decision at any point during the posting period.
Position Details DISTRICT MISSION: At PPS, our goal is that by the end of elementary, middle and high school every student by name is meeting or exceeding academic standards and is fully prepared to make productive life decisions. DISTRICT PROFILE: To obtain more information about our district, schools, learning environment and programs, please go to https://www.pps.net/Domain/265. Key points of the job description for a Varsity Head Coach: High ethical and professional standards. Direct a successful grade 9-12 program and oversee all facets of an entire community youth program. 3 years of High School coaching experience Be a role model for high school student-athletes. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports by encouraging student-athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program. Lead student-athletes in the support of other Portland Public Schools athletics and activities.
The Head Coach will be responsible for the following: Manage all aspects of the high school program including training, practice schedules and routines. Hire and oversee a staff of assistant coaches Provide regular communication with parents/families Regularly track the academic progress of all student athletes in the program and facilitate necessary supports to ensure their academic eligibility. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports and encourage athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program for athletics.
All new hired coaches will need to complete the following prior to employment: NFHS/ASEP Certification First Aid Card (CPR and AED trained) District Fingerprinting/Criminal check Completion of OSAA Concussion Test Completion of ODE Steroid Test Completion of OSAA Heat Test *Head Up Football *Cheer and Dance/Drill Spirit Safety Training Completion of Portland Public School District paperwork and trainings.
Applicant will be asked to apply online at our website and include the following: A cover letter detailing your experience. A current resume. A minimum of three letters of recommendation/reference. All PPS job offers are contingent on the satisfactory completion of a background check, including fingerprinting and criminal records. Salary Range - $6100.00 to $10,000.00 * There is no compensation for summer and out of season workouts.
Portland Public Schools (PPS) is seeking talented people from diverse backgrounds and experiences to lead change and inspire PPS students. At PPS, every employee, despite having different roles, is an educator. We hope to attract talented educators who model the core PPS Educator Essentials. With the District’s focus on eliminating systemic racism and its adverse impact on student learning, we seek to hire individuals who bring to our district a deep commitment to racial equity and social justice. The District is committed to equal opportunity and nondiscrimination in all its educational and employment activities. The District prohibits discrimination based on perceived or actual race; national or ethnic origin; color; sex; religion; age; sexual orientation; gender expression or identity; pregnancy; marital status; veteran’s status; familial status; economic status or source of income; mental or physical disability or perceived disability; or military service. 504 Coordinator: Marquita Guzman,mguzman@pps.net, 971-393-8633 ADA Coordinator: Jey Buno, jbuno@pps.net, 503-916-3360 Civil Rights Director: Dr. Bobby Cruz, bcruz@pps.net, 503-839-3660 Accessibility Statement Conflict/Complaint Resolution Process
