Job.JobTitle: JH Track Coach - 2 Positions (JH Track Assistant)
Job.JobDescription:
JH Track Assistant - Level E $2644-$3039
Must Obtain the Following Credentials Favorable BCI Background Check Favorable FBI Background Check CPR First Aid for Coaches/Sports Safety Training Fundamentals of Coaching Certification Concussion Training Sudden Cardiac Arrest Training Pupil Validation Permit from ODE
Application must be completed to be considered.
QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program. 2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports) 3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions. REPORTS TO: The athletic director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principals SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal. JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self discipline, self confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc. GENERAL: 1. The success of athletic programs has a strong influence on the community's image of the entire system. The public exposure is a considerable responsibility and community/parent pressure for winning performance is taxing, but must not override the objectives of good sportsmanship and good mental health. 2. The position includes other unusual aspect such as extended time, risk injury factor and due process predicaments. 3. It is the express intent of this job description to give sufficient guidance to function. In cases not specifically covered, it shall be assumed that a coach shall exercise common sense and good judgment. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: 1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Schools' Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation by the entire staff of the sports program. 2. Has knowledge of existing system, state and league regulations; implements same consistently and interprets them for staff. 3. Understands the proper administrative line of command and refers all requests or grievances through proper channels. Is aware of all public/staff/departmental meetings that require attendance. STAFF RESPONSIBILITIES: 4. Established the fundamental philosophy, skills and techniques to be taught by staff. Designs conferences, clinics and staff meetings to insure staff awareness of overall program. 5. Trains and informs staff, encourages professional growth by encouraging clinic attendance according to local clinic policy. 6. Delegates specific duties, supervises implementation and, at season's end, analyzes staff effectiveness and evaluates all assistants. 7. Maintains discipline, adjusts grievances and works to increase morale and cooperation. 8. Performs such other duties which may be assigned by the athletic director/principal. ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES: (and so on...)

Job.JobTitle: Supplemental - MS Assistant Girls Track Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Supplemental - MS Assistant Girls Track Coach position at Licking Valley Middle School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Supplemental - MS Assistant Girls Track Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Licking Valley Middle School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Supplemental - MS Assistant Girls Track Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Supplemental - MS Assistant Girls Track Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Supplemental - MS Assistant Girls Track Coach role at Licking Valley Middle School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: Supplemental - Varsity Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Supplemental - Varsity Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach position at Licking Valley High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Supplemental - Varsity Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Supplemental - Varsity Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach at Licking Valley High School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Licking Valley High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Supplemental - Varsity Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Supplemental - Varsity Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Supplemental - Varsity Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach position at Licking Valley High School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobTitle: Head Coach - Middle School Boys Track
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Coach - Middle School Boys Track at Trey Newberry is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Head Coach - Middle School Boys Track are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Trey Newberry use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Head Coach - Middle School Boys Track recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Head Coach - Middle School Boys Track collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Head Coach - Middle School Boys Track maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Trey Newberry. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach role at Lincoln High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Lincoln High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Lincoln High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach at Lincoln High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Additional Information: Perrysburg Junior High is seeking an Asst Track Coach . Applicant must have or be able to obtain all certifications required by OHSAA in order to coach as well as complete a BCI/FBI background check. If you have any questions, please contact Andrea Monheim, Junior High Athletic Director at amonheim@perrysburgschools.net
Qualifications: 1. Valid driver's license 2. State of Ohio Teaching License (preferred, not required). 3. Coaching and administrative abilities. 4. Required to maintain a valid CPR card, BCI and certification from the Ohio Department of Education through the Pupil Activity Validation Program. Proof of both certificates must be on file with the Athletic Director prior to coaching. 5. Ability to relate to, communicate with and inspire young athletes. 6. Knowledge of prevention and care of athletic injuries. 7. Organizational skills/resources to enhance the program. 8. Skill in oral presentations. 9. Ability to get along with other coaches. 10. Desire to invest time during season. 11. Knowledge of the sport with emphasis on fundamentals. 12. Knowledge of training and conditioning techniques. 13. Ability to diagnose player deficiencies and prescribe corrective activities. 14. Ability to make minor repairs on equipment. 15. Professional tact, diplomacy and presentation with administrators, staff, teachers, students, parents and the community. 16. Conscientious and assumes responsibility for own work. 17. Good health, high moral character and good attendance record. 18. Demonstrate enthusiasm and a sincere desire to aid all students.

The Track and Field - Assistant Coaches (2) at Brad Whitlatch is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Track and Field - Assistant Coaches (2) is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Brad Whitlatch, the Track and Field - Assistant Coaches (2) helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Track and Field - Assistant Coaches (2) may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Brad Whitlatch well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Track and Field - Assistant Coaches (2) follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobTitle: Head JV Volleyball Coach - E801SY2526 | Open Until Filled
Job.JobDescription:
GENERAL DUTIES: Support the Hillsboro School District athletic objective, policy of interscholastic athletics, and Hillsboro School District Athletic Code. The District believes that extra-curricular activities are an integral part of school life. All students, regardless of their ability, should take part if possible to be able to grow physically, intellectually, and socially through participation. Coaches organize and conduct the athletic programs to meet the needs of the school district and their participants.
ESSENTIAL REQUIREMENTS:
Experience in and/or knowledge of the sport, coaching techniques, and student supervision. Ability and willingness to effectively communicate in verbal and written modes with student/athletes, parents, assistant coaches, and other school staff. Ability and willingness to perform coaching responsibilities in accordance with school and District procedures and policies. Must have current CPR/First Aid certification. Must have current Concussion Management and other trainings required by the OSAA. Maintain integrity of confidential information relating to students, staff, or District patrons. The ability to work harmoniously with others and collaborate solutions to concerns. Successfully pass background check.

Job.JobDescription:
The MS Field Hockey Head Coach at CAMS North is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the MS Field Hockey Head Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At CAMS North, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The MS Field Hockey Head Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The MS Field Hockey Head Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at CAMS North operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent CAMS North with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the MS Field Hockey Head Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the MS Field Hockey Head Coach role at CAMS North.
Job.CompanyDescription: Chambersburg Area School D. coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The HS Boys Volleyball JV Coach role at Chambersburg Senior High emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the HS Boys Volleyball JV Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Chambersburg Senior High, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The HS Boys Volleyball JV Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Chambersburg Senior High at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The HS Boys Volleyball JV Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The HS Boys Volleyball JV Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The HS Boys Volleyball JV Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Chambersburg Senior High.
Job.CompanyDescription: Chambersburg Area School D. coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The HS Assistant Football Coach at Chambersburg Senior High is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the HS Assistant Football Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Chambersburg Senior High, the HS Assistant Football Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The HS Assistant Football Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Chambersburg Senior High well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The HS Assistant Football Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription:
The High School JV Softball Coach plays a vital role in the development of student-athletes by fostering teamwork, discipline, and a strong work ethic. Working in collaboration with the head coach and varsity staff, the JV coach supports the overall vision of the softball program by focusing on fundamental skill development, game knowledge, and player growth. Responsibilities include assisting with practice planning, teaching core softball skills such as hitting, fielding, throwing, pitching, and base running, preparing athletes for competition, and promoting sportsmanship and respect on and off the field. The JV coach helps create a positive and inclusive team environment that emphasizes effort, accountability, and character, supporting student-athletes as they build confidence, leadership skills, and a lifelong appreciation for the game of softball.
Primary Duties and Responsibilities:
Function within the philosophy and objectives developed by the District’s interscholastic athletic programs as well as within guidelines available in the Co-Curricular Manual and in building manuals. Enhance coaching skills through subscription to professional journals, membership in professional associations and attendance at clinics. Administer emergency treatment of injuries in the absence of a trainer, physician or other person more qualified than him/herself. Project a positive model for student-athletes, the general student body, and the community at large through appearance, positive attitude, enthusiastic personality, emotional maturity, self-control, leadership, planning, preparation, and good sportsmanship. Teach each athlete skills necessary for the appropriate position in the sport, using proven and up-to-date coaching techniques. Maintain total loyalty, support of, and communication with the head coach and program while assisting the former in physical, mental and skills preparation of the student-athletes. Apply disciplinary procedures fairly and in concert with those of the head coach, school and District. Effectively utilize practice time allotted by the head coach in the prescribed manner to further individual and team performance. Complete additional duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or assigned principal.
Where: Central York High School 601 Mundis Mill Road York, PA 17406
Qualifications: * Combination of education and experience necessary to perform the tasks outlined in this job description * Must have (or willing to obtain) current PA Criminal, PA Child Abuse and FBI Fingerprint History Background Clearances.

The Girls Lacrosse - Assistant Coach position at William Tennent High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Girls Lacrosse - Assistant Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Girls Lacrosse - Assistant Coach at William Tennent High School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At William Tennent High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Girls Lacrosse - Assistant Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Girls Lacrosse - Assistant Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Girls Lacrosse - Assistant Coach position at William Tennent High School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The AGHS Football Coach - Defensive Coordinator at Avon Grove High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the AGHS Football Coach - Defensive Coordinator plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Avon Grove High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The AGHS Football Coach - Defensive Coordinator expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the AGHS Football Coach - Defensive Coordinator supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the AGHS Football Coach - Defensive Coordinator may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Avon Grove High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The Assistant III Girls Lacrosse Coach position at Quakertown High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Assistant III Girls Lacrosse Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Quakertown High School, the Assistant III Girls Lacrosse Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Assistant III Girls Lacrosse Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Assistant III Girls Lacrosse Coach at Quakertown High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Flag Football - Girls' Varsity Assistant Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Flag Football - Girls' Varsity Assistant Coach at North Hills School District is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Flag Football - Girls' Varsity Assistant Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at North Hills School District use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Flag Football - Girls' Varsity Assistant Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Flag Football - Girls' Varsity Assistant Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Flag Football - Girls' Varsity Assistant Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at North Hills School District. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The Baseball - 9th Grade Assistant Coach position at North Hills School District is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Baseball - 9th Grade Assistant Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At North Hills School District, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Baseball - 9th Grade Assistant Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Baseball - 9th Grade Assistant Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Baseball - 9th Grade Assistant Coach role at North Hills School District is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The Crew Head Coach at Upper Merion Area is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Crew Head Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Upper Merion Area, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Crew Head Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Crew Head Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Crew Head Coach at Upper Merion Area allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobDescription:
EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER 2.3.26 Cheltenham School District announces the following ANTICIPATED extra duty-extra pay position(s) is available for the 2026-2027 school-year, at Cheltenham High School:
Field Hockey - Head Coach
Reports to: Athletic Director
Job Description: 1. Responsible for assisting the Head Coach with the development, implementation, and monitoring of the athletic program for the assigned sport. 2. Assist the Head Coach with the supervision of participants of the assigned sport during program related activities. 3. Serve as a positive role model to the student athletes and represent the Cheltenham School district in a well-respected manner. 4. Must demonstrate an ability to work cooperatively and enthusiastically with the entire school community. 5. Must demonstrate strong interpersonal skills.
Qualifications Must have extensive knowledge of the sport and the ability to effectively teach and communicate fundamental skills. Must have at least 2 - 4 years of coaching experience working with children and/or adolescents: coaching at the high school level preferred. A strong understanding of the sport's theory and practice is required; experience as a player or coach at the high school or collegiate level is preferred.

EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER 1.14.26 Cheltenham School District announces the following extra duty-extra pay position(s) is available for the 2025-2026 school-year, at Cheltenham High School:
Lacrosse [Boys] - Assistant Coach
Must have extensive knowledge of the sport and the ability to effectively teach and communicate fundamental skills. Must have at least 2 - 4 years of coaching experience working with children and/or adolescents; coaching at the high school level preferred. A strong understanding of the sport's theory and practice is required; experience as a player or coach at the high school or collegiate level is preferred. Must demonstrate the personal qualities necessary to foster sportsmanship and support student-athlete success in a positive and encouraging environment. The ideal candidate will possess excellent communication, organizational, and collaboration skills, along with a proven ability to build relationships with student-athletes, parents, staff, and school administration. Applicants must be prepared to submit required background checks that are no more than one year old from the date of issue, in accordance with state law.

Experience working with students is preferred. Salary is based on a set stipend

Job.JobDescription:
The High School Assistant Girls Tennis Coach plays a vital role in the development of student-athletes by fostering sportsmanship, discipline, and a strong work ethic. Working in collaboration with the head coach and varsity staff, the assistant coach supports the overall vision of the girls tennis program by focusing on fundamental skill development, match strategy, and player growth. Responsibilities include assisting with practice planning and implementation, teaching core tennis skills such as proper stroke mechanics (forehand, backhand, serve, and volley), footwork, court positioning, and match play strategy. The assistant coach helps prepare athletes for competition by organizing drills, supervising challenge matches, and reinforcing rules knowledge and sportsmanship. In addition, the Assistant Girls Tennis Coach promotes a positive and inclusive team environment that emphasizes effort, accountability, and character both on and off the court. The coach supports student-athletes in building confidence, resilience, leadership abilities, and a lifelong appreciation for the sport of tennis.
Primary Duties and Responsibilities:
Function within the philosophy and objectives developed by the District’s interscholastic athletic programs as well as within guidelines available in the Co-Curricular Manual and in building manuals. Enhance coaching skills through subscription to professional journals, membership in professional associations and attendance at clinics. Administer emergency treatment of injuries in the absence of a trainer, physician or other person more qualified than him/herself. Project a positive model for student-athletes, the general student body, and the community at large through appearance, positive attitude, enthusiastic personality, emotional maturity, self-control, leadership, planning, preparation, and good sportsmanship. Teach each athlete skills necessary for the appropriate position in the sport, using proven and up-to-date coaching techniques. Maintain total loyalty, support of, and communication with the head coach and program while assisting the former in physical, mental and skills preparation of the student-athletes. Apply disciplinary procedures fairly and in concert with those of the head coach, school and District. Effectively utilize practice time allotted by the head coach in the prescribed manner to further individual and team performance. Complete additional duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or assigned principal.
Where: Central York High School 601 Mundis Mill Road York, PA 17406
Qualifications: * Combination of education and experience necessary to perform the tasks outlined in this job description * Must have (or willing to obtain) current PA Criminal, PA Child Abuse and FBI Fingerprint History Background Clearances.

The Middle School Field Hockey Assistant Coach plays a vital role in the development of student-athletes by fostering teamwork, discipline, and a strong work ethic. Working collaboratively with the head coach, the assistant coach supports the overall vision of the field hockey program by emphasizing fundamental skill development, game strategy, and individual growth. Responsibilities include assisting with practice planning, teaching core field hockey techniques such as stick skills, passing, receiving, shooting, and defensive positioning, preparing athletes for competition, and promoting sportsmanship and respect both on and off the field. The assistant coach helps cultivate a positive, inclusive team environment that values effort, accountability, and character, while supporting student-athletes as they build confidence, leadership skills, and a lifelong appreciation for the game of field hockey.
Primary Duties and Responsibilities:
Function within the philosophy and objectives developed by the District’s interscholastic athletic programs as well as within guidelines available in the Co-Curricular Manual and in building manuals. Enhance coaching skills through subscription to professional journals, membership in professional associations and attendance at clinics. Administer emergency treatment of injuries in the absence of a trainer, physician or other person more qualified than him/herself. Project a positive model for student-athletes, the general student body, and the community at large through appearance, positive attitude, enthusiastic personality, emotional maturity, self-control, leadership, planning, preparation, and good sportsmanship. Teach each athlete skills necessary for the appropriate position in the sport, using proven and up-to-date coaching techniques. Maintain total loyalty, support of, and communication with the head coach and program while assisting the former in physical, mental and skills preparation of the student-athletes. Apply disciplinary procedures fairly and in concert with those of the head coach, school and District. Effectively utilize practice time allotted by the head coach in the prescribed manner to further individual and team performance. Complete additional duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or assigned principal.
Where: Central York Middle School 1950 North Hills Road York, PA 17406
Qualifications: * Combination of education and experience necessary to perform the tasks outlined in this job description * Must have (or willing to obtain) current PA Criminal, PA Child Abuse and FBI Fingerprint History Background Clearances.

Job.JobTitle: Boys' Wrestling - Head Middle School Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Boys' Wrestling - Head Middle School Coach role at Cornwall-Lebanon School District is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Boys' Wrestling - Head Middle School Coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Cornwall-Lebanon School District, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Boys' Wrestling - Head Middle School Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Cornwall-Lebanon School District, the Boys' Wrestling - Head Middle School Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Boys' Wrestling - Head Middle School Coach at Cornwall-Lebanon School District is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.
Job.Location: Cedar Crest Middle School 101 East Evergreen Road Lebanon, PA 17042

Job.JobDescription:
Position Title: Varsity Assistant Girls' Volleyball Coach
Job Goal: This position involves coaching, mentoring, and guiding student-athletes in individual skill development and team strategies. The coach will also be responsible for fostering a positive and inclusive team culture, ensuring the safety and well-being of players, and always representing the school professionally.
Qualifications
Minimum of 3 years coaching experience (head coaching preferred) Proven coaching techniques and in-depth knowledge, including rules, strategies, and district and PIAA regulations Strong communication, organizational, and leadership skills Ability to foster effective relationships with administrators, staff, students, parents, and governing bodies Commitment to academic and personal development of student-athletes Ability to assess and develop players and coaches Professional demeanor and motivational leadership Effective communicator with strong human relations skills Commitment to equity, diversity, and inclusion Willingness to uphold school policies and work flexible hours, including evenings and weekends Availability to meet with students and parents outside of instructional hours A head coach/assistant coach must be dedicated to organizing and maintaining a structured off-season workout program that supports the ongoing development of their athletes. This involves planning and supervising conditioning, skill-building, and strength training sessions to ensure progress throughout the year and team readiness.
Application Process:
All required clearances must comply with the Pennsylvania Department of Education's mandated criteria for hire. Questions may be directed to the Athletics Department at 717-270-6770 or asinico@lebanon.k12.pa.us All required clearances must comply with the Pennsylvania Department of Education's mandated criteria for hire.
Application Deadline: The position will remain open until the appropriate candidate is selected.
The Lebanon School District is an equal-opportunity employer.

The Lebanon School District is one of the oldest school districts in Pennsylvania. From teachers and parents to our alumni, volunteers, and community partners, there is a strong commitment to continuously improve educational opportunities for our students.
Our City, Our Cedars, and YOU! Become part of the Cedar family. Our staff is appreciated, trusted, and empowered to be difference makers for our students.

Job.JobDescription:
The Baseball - 9th Grade Head Coach at North Hills School District is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Baseball - 9th Grade Head Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at North Hills School District reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Baseball - 9th Grade Head Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Baseball - 9th Grade Head Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Baseball - 9th Grade Head Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at North Hills School District. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Adjunct Coach Girls Distance Track Coach
Job.JobDescription:
ADJUNCT COACH GIRLS DISTANCE TRACK COACH (JOB ID: 26234)
Our Human Resources Team at the Greenville County School District is dedicated to advancing student achievement by recruiting and employing the highest qualified staff for our schools and to serve those with whom we work.
Summary: Athletic positions require someone with proven decision-making skills, a track record of initiative and effort and a commitment to young people and education. Our jobs require a "people person" that indicates through actions a personality that is conducive to positive interactions with students, staff and parents.
To view the job description for each type of athletic coach, click here on the Athletics Position Descriptions. Click here on the Supplements for Athletics link to see athletics supplementary salary schedule.
Coaching positions require the following Continuing Education Requirements: GCS Safety Videos Required Annually: · Bloodborne Pathogen Exposure Prevention · FERPA: Confidentiality of Records · GCS – Title IX & Safe Schools · GCS – Code of Ethics & Social Media · GCS – Information Security Mgmt System · GCS – Safety Training · GCS – Mandated Reporter · Greenville Energy Conservation

POSITION PURPOSE: Prepares each participating student athlete for competition in sports activities, and helps them to achieve a high level of skill, an appreciation for the values of discipline and sportsmanship, and an increased level of self-esteem. ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: - Prioritize athletics as a supplemental program to support the academic mission of the school. - Carry out the aims and objectives of the sports program as outlined by the Athletic Director and school district administration. - Instruct athletes in individual and team fundamentals, sportsmanship, cooperation, strategy and playing tactics, and physical conditioning necessary to realize individual and team success. - Assist the Athletic Director in scheduling intramural and interscholastic contests. - Assist in planning and scheduling a regular program of practice in season. - Maintain required attendance forms, insurance records, and other related documents. - Assist in oversight of safety conditions in the facility or area in which the assigned sport is conducted at all times student athletes are present. - Assist in establishing and implementing performance criteria for academic eligibility in interscholastic competition of the identified sport. - Enforce code of conduct standards and sportsmanlike behavior at all times; establish and oversee penalties for breach of standards by student athletes. - Recommend purchase of equipment, supplies, uniforms, etc. as appropriate. ADDITIONAL DUTIES: Performs other related tasks as assigned by the Athletic Director, Principal, Superintendent or other district office administrator as designated by the Superintendent. QUALIFICATIONS: - Previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. - Knowledge and/or background in the assigned sport. - Teaching certificate and experience preferred. - Must be able to pass criminal background check. - Valid drivers license. EXPERIENCE: - Must have knowledge of South Carolina High School League rules and eligibility. - Must be cooperative, service-oriented, and able to work effectively with frequent interruptions.
Job.Experience: Previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Baseball Coach - Middle School at Fort Mill School District 4 is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Assistant Baseball Coach - Middle School are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Fort Mill School District 4 use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Assistant Baseball Coach - Middle School recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Assistant Baseball Coach - Middle School collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Assistant Baseball Coach - Middle School maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Fort Mill School District 4. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.
Job.Location: Springfield Middle School - Fort Mill, South Carolina

Job.JobTitle: 2026-2027 Temporary Employee- Head JV Cheer Coach- Hanahan High
Job.JobDescription:
The 2026-2027 Temporary Employee- Head JV Cheer Coach- Hanahan High position at Hanahan High provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Job.JobTitle: ASST. GIRLS SOCCER ADJUNCT COACH (JOB ID: 24325)
Job.JobDescription:
Our Human Resources Team at the Greenville County School District is dedicated to advancing student achievement by recruiting and employing the highest qualified staff for our schools and to serve those with whom we work.
Summary: Athletic positions require someone with proven decision-making skills, a track record of initiative and effort and a commitment to young people and education. Our jobs require a “people person” that indicates through actions a personality that is conducive to positive interactions with students, staff and parents.
To view the job description for each type of athletic coach, click here on the Athletics Position Descriptions. Click here on the Supplements for Athletics link to see athletics supplementary salary schedule.
Coaching positions require the following Continuing Education Requirements: - GCS Safety Videos Required Annually: - Bloodborne Pathogen Exposure Prevention - FERPA: Confidentiality of Records - GCS – Title IX & Safe Schools - GCS – Code of Ethics & Social Media - GCS – Information Security Mgmt System - GCS – Safety Training - GCS – Mandated Reporter - Greenville Energy Conservation

Position Title: Head Coach Department: Athletics Reports To: Athletic Director SUMMARY: To help each participating student achieve a high level of skill, an appreciation for the values of discipline and sportsmanship, and an increased level of self-esteem. ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Coaches individuals in the skills necessary for excellent achievement in the sport involved. Plans and schedules a regular program of practice in season. Oversees the safety conditions of the facility or area in which assigned sport is conducted at all times that students are present. Maintains accurate statistics, records, and results of the season. Enforces discipline and sportsmanlike behavior at all times, and establishes and oversees penalties for breach of such standards by individual students. Maintains competency in rules, rule interpretations, meet procedures, coaching techniques, and general information about all aspects of the sport. Establishes performance criteria for eligibility in interscholastic competition in this sport and is consistent in establishing criteria for eligibility in competition. Adheres to a highly efficient and technically sound program of injury prevention and follow up. Works closely with the athletics director in scheduling intramural and interscholastic contests. Recommends purchase of equipment, supplies, and uniforms. Maintains necessary attendance forms, insurance records, and similar paperwork. Accounts for all equipment or delegates the responsibility. Develops a consistent and positive public communications procedure through the school and media to inform the parents and the general public about the athletic program. Performs other duties as may be assigned by the Supervisor. JOB SPECIFICATIONS SUPERVISORY RESPONSIBILITIES: Supervises students of particular program. Carries out supervisory responsibilities in accordance with the district's policies and applicable laws. QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENTS: To perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty in a pleasant, professional, efficient manner. Must be reliable, responsible and dependable and fulfill obligations. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skill, and/or ability required. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. EDUCATION and/or EXPERIENCE: To be decided by Executive Director and/or Building Principal. CERTIFICATES, LICENSES, REGISTRATIONS: Valid South Carolina Teaching Certificate, if applicable. LANGUAGE SKILLS: Ability to read and interpret documents such as safety rules, operating and maintenance instructions, and procedure manuals. Ability to write routine reports and correspondence. Ability to speak effectively before administrators, staff, parents and students. MATHEMATICAL SKILLS: Ability to calculate figures and amounts such as discounts, interest, commissions, proportions, percentages, area, circumference, and volume. Ability to apply concepts of basic algebra and geometry. REASONING ABILITY: Ability to interpret and apply common sense understanding in carrying out instructions furnished in written, oral, diagram or schedule form. Ability to analyze information and use logic to address work related issues and problems. Ability to solve practical problems and deal with a variety of concrete variables in situations where only limited standardization exists. OTHER SKILLS and ABILITIES: Ability to apply knowledge of current research and theory in specific field. Ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships with students, staff and the community. Ability to communicate clearly and concisely both in oral and written form. Ability to perform duties with awareness of all district requirements and Board of Education policies. PHYSICAL DEMANDS: The physical demands described here are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. While performing the duties of this job, the employee is frequently required to sit; occasionally walk and stand; travel from building to other sites. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision, distance vision, depth perception, and the ability to adjust focus. The employee is required to be able to hear conversations in quiet environments. WORK ENVIRONMENT: The work environment characteristics described here are representative of those an employee encounters while performing the essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. While performing the duties of this job, the employee regularly works inside. The employee must be able to meet deadlines with severe time constraints. The employee is frequently will work irregular or extended work hours while performing the duties of this job. The employee is directly responsible for safety, well-being and work output of students and coaches. The noise level in the work environment varies from quiet to loud.
Job.CompanyDescription: Aiken County Public Sch. coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The JV Girls Soccer - Head Coach position at Northwestern High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the JV Girls Soccer - Head Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Northwestern High School, the JV Girls Soccer - Head Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The JV Girls Soccer - Head Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the JV Girls Soccer - Head Coach at Northwestern High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.
